RATING: 6
I played a lot of chess one year. Somehow got to 1900 ELO on chess.com 
Wasn't good at it but for every move i'd sit literally for hours thinking about every decision before committing to one (i often played correspondence chess, where you had a lot of time to make a move).

I absolutely love the mind-games aspect of it. But i don't like abstract games, nor heavy memorization and dry pattern recognition.
On the other hand, on a casual level those aren't required.

Chess has staying staying power no doubt. It is well rounded and deep. 
Just not what i'm looking for fun-wise.

RATING: 10
The problem with a rating system that takes account of every one of thousands (?) of ratings is that everything ends up between 5.2 and 7.6.  Really, Chess:6.963 out of 10.  By pure coincidence that's were Earth was rated by 1,000,000 alien nations.  I can understand if you say you'd prefer to play Advanced Squad Leader or Awful Green Things From Outer Space but show you have a sense of perspective people! Chess is a truly awesome battle of intellects, think Fisher vs Spaskey - when did another board game ever capture the imagination of the planet in such a way?  If you rate chess at 6.9 or less you mustn't be any good at it!

RATING: 7
Chess is a classic, but you have to religiously study it to be great at it.  I prefer games where someone with zero (or relatively little) experience can jump in, figure out the dynamics, and outstrategize their opponents.  With chess, you have to memorize all kinds of openings, strategies, and such to be really great.  I prefer Chess 960 (the Bobby Fischer variant) to straight-up Chess.

RATING: 9.5

I'll play this when I'm in the mood for an intellectual exercise; but when I want relaxed fun, I'll play something else. That said, the game is very much a classic that is very traditional and a part of our culture, and I think it is a very good game to know how to play well. With a chess clock and a short time limit for each player (i.e. Speed Chess), the game is INTENSE and way fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
An enduring classic, and deservedly so (though overanalyzed), but it just doesn't grab me. It feels a bit limited and seems to reward memorization of certain gamestates to an extreme degree. It is easy to teach and makes a good "gateway" game, but for my gaming time there are fresher, more interesting, and more fun games out there (for the time investment, at least). There are almost certainly better abstracts in terms of strategic depth and balance, but cultural inertia makes it unlikely that any game to come will be played by a larger group of people. For me at least, it's better as an intellectual exercise than as a game.

RATING: 7
I'm not a Chess fanatic.  I enjoy the game, I know how the pieces move and the general tactics and strategy in the game.  I do not know the names for the beginning sequences or anything like that.

In fact, I really dislike that aspect of chess - that's it's so well known and has been played so much that you're just acting out a script, until someone deviates from it.  You're playing out the same games other people have, over and over again.

I'd rather play Go or Navia Dratp, but Chess enjoys widespread popularity and I still enjoy playing ... against people who regard it as a game!

RATING: 9
Easily my most played game.  Most of those plays were online blitz long before I discovered modern games.  

I always wanted to be good at chess, but the need to study/memorize openings always felt like work.  I also often didn't enjoy games without time limits as I always preferred to move quickly rather than analyze every move to death.  For these reasons, and despite playing it a ton, I never progressed beyond an intermediate level.

Now that I have played so many modern games, I'm much less enthusiastic about chess.  A game played quickly and aggressively between two evenly matched players is still a great experience though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2009-09-12
Can you see the great theme, where two mighty kingdoms battle fiercely against each other in esperate battle?

2015-04-23
4->5
Staying true to my other ratings, I cannot honestly have Chess rated as a "four". It is a solid abstract even at today's standards. There is nothing broken about it.

The game has a rather steep learning curve for an abstract. First, all pieces follow unique rules of movement. Once you have the basics mastered, you have to memorise several openings to avoid check-mate in first few rounds. Next you have to train yourself to concentrate so that you can easily plan several moves ahead. To master Chess you have to play a lot which is something very few are willing to do.

I certainly understand why many people do not enjoy playing Chess. It takes so much computing power to go through all possible permutations and in the end you still end up doing something silly and get kicked into face for it. But at least compared to Go, Chess is easier to analyse. Usually, key plays change the balance on the board immediately so that it is easier to see what went wrong and learn from your mistakes. And the fact that Chess does not shine in casual / occasional playing will keep people away. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I am a rather unorthodox Chess player. My strategies tend to be random at best. Usually I am looking so far ahead into other players strategies that I miss obvious moves.  And while I can hold my own if I have to, it is not my favorite game to play. Granted, in eighth grade I did organize a Chess group in my math class, but that was more to get out of math than it was because I was passionate about Chess. 

The one person I have never played against is my husband - he was a master Chess player back in high school - playing those five-minute crazy timed Chess matches and winning every time. I respect him too much to submit him to my insane tactics. (Why is it everyone forgets that the king can attack? Sure, it probably won't win you the game, but it's not like he's a totally worthless piece!)

However, that said, I do have the most beautiful fantasy Chess set. In truth, I have it more because the figures are just awesome than because I regularly play.

RATING: 10
Chess gets no respect on the geek. The body of analysis, culture and lore around chess have lifted it to extraordinary heights.  I know that the same can be said of Go and Bridge, and some other games, but all that attention wasn't lavished for no reason.  The only problem with the game is that it induces madness, obsession, psychotic competitiveness and sadism in so many.  Still the most satisfying game I've ever played, though not always the most fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Now that this game has been cemented as one of my few 10s, I'm adding some high-modality commentary!

As a solo game, or a 'science', Chess is unparallelled. Your goals can be diverse, but are always achievable. No matter your level, you can always be better. Unlike other games, the horizon can be grasped. If you are 2700+ then you're playing for a living, anyway, so it's not a game anymore for you!

A lot has been said about how you must know this opening, or that, and while I would dispute the notion that knowing a game well is a hindrance to its play, at the same time, the 'sport' in Chess comes from identifying positions that you think will make your opponent psychologically uncomfortable. For instance, I play 1. d4 exculsively, so a King's side player who prefers sharp, tactical play is at an advantage if she can bend the position to those preferences. This struggle might only be apparent to experienced players, but most games require a level of experience to appreciate. 

I adore several variants of Chess. While I prefer 5-10 minute games in real life, I also love Bughouse Chess - the game that provided me with some of the most joyous experiences as a teenager discovering gaming during high school. I find the 'art' of Chess accessible under time pressure, where moves find themselves and profundity happens!

Comparisons with GO and other lifestyle abstracts: I appreciate the GO is more 'intuitive' but I have been heartened to see my instincts confirmed by the recent news computers beat GO players now, as they do Chess players. Technophobia aside, I prefer Chess because of the aesthetic - the different functions of the pieces provide different themes to games, whereas GO relies strongly on the player to create the narrative. With the wealth of culture behind these two games, I don't think any other game rivals. In the end, my preferences lie with a fascination for Soviet and European history and culture over Asian culture, even if overall both intrigue me.

RATING: 5
What can be said about this game that hasn't already been said?? A Classic? Sure, of course. Pure abstract strategy? Absolutely. But to me, chess almost always ends up with one or the other player beating their head against a wall. Because it's been around for so long and so much has been written about the game, it just comes down to who has done their homework in many cases. The player with the most experience will almost always win. It's a good game but it's very situational. The game requires quite a bit of effort to get good at and once you can say you are 'good', no one wants to play with you! You have to have players who are closely matched in skill level to make it interesting. Without some sort of matching the game becomes pointless for both players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I've always enjoyed chess, but as a game I feel like it devolves once one side has been largely taken out and suddenly you have to figure out how to pin the King down. Maybe if you have memorized end game moves, you will know how to make this a smooth and quick process. But I've always found it very difficult to achieve, and very easy to continue evading a capture, dragging the game out artificially (with, sometimes, a surprise turnaround). Ultimately, it's a bit tedious.

(This sort of tedious, extended game of trying to pin down ferrets is also the impression I get from my few tries at Go, and possibly why I wasn't particularly attracted to it. At least Chess has a part which isn't that!)

From a greater standpoint, I feel like the game was always intended to be a great simulation of war, and allow people to develop their brains to think in terms of how things work on the battlefield. Which, then, you play the game and it's like...yeah...probably not.

I mean, granted, I'm not a soldier, a general, nor military strategist, so perhaps I'm wrong. But the game fails to capture such issues as terrain, spies, training, and supply networks. Most ancient battles, purportedly, were not set-piece confrontations in an open field, they were sieges to take over centers of power or commerce. Tafl games probably are based on this siege-centric reality to war and so may be a better game if war simulation is the goal.

But more importantly, chess always seems to come down to running through a wide variety of iterations of possible options, to develop an optimal path. A real battle, I sense, is probably more like playing paper-rock-scissors, where you have to guess whether the other guy is going to go left or right, so that you zig or zag appropriately.

Neuroshima Hex is probably (again - not being an expert - but in my opinion) a much better simulation of a battle than chess is. You would have commanders moving people around into different positions, eyeing the other teams troops, to try and spot a moment of advantage and then call in the attack. Once that begins, it will mostly unfold on its own and you're just stuck with the results, hoping that you read everything correctly. Except, of course, in a real battle you would be operating in a fog of war. And chess doesn't even have that.

So...chess is a decent game. But I like to rate things to at least some extent based on what I think the designer was actually trying to achieve. In this case, I feel like it was a bit of a failure, which just happened to be fun despite the fact.

RATING: 10
Ultra competitive tournament game with no ceiling for skill.

Complexity - none, extremely simple rules

Strategy - unlimited, better player will win

Luck - none, slight advantage to being white but no luck in the game

Interaction - extreme, every move you make effects the other player

Fun - varies, equal skilled opponents will get enjoyment out of challenges. Different skilled opponents will not be able to enjoy the game in its true glory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Slow and un-fun brainburner, while I don't mind thinking and strategy a round of chess still feels like an hour-long chore. I've never been a fan of party games but this one goes too far the other way, leaving absolutly zero room for table talk while you're supposed to brood over your secret strategies in total, dead-serious silence.

Other issues are the game's unforgiving nature (an early mistake leaves little room for recovery) and how it promotes excessive turtling, the lack of luck factor (hence nothing to blame when you loose), and how it already has been analyzed to death. It just leaves no opening for devising your own optimal strategies (an essential part of any game) when the opponent already has read up on dozens of superior ones.

Positive aspects includes easy-to-obtain components and that most people knows the basic rules, just don't expect them to know the finer details like en-passants and castling (the latter which I did wrong for several years without anyone noticing). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Obviously a historically great game. Doesn't speak to me because

1) I am not a huge fan of abstracts,
2) its popularity means that a great deal of study and practice is required to be "good" at the game, and
3) computers are now better than the best humans at it.

Many plays a long time ago.

RATING: 5.5
Classic. Probably the biggest problem with this game is that the results of centuries of study into the best tactics have been unevenly distributed over the playerbase. Someone with more knowledge and mental vocabulary (e.g. standard openings, pinning pieces, forking, etc) will almost always win from someone without, and it's hard for a new player to pick up this knowledge just from playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm not sure where I learned chess. I remember being introduced to it as a kid, trying to appreciate the game in college, and losing to a friend's young daughter in my mid-20s. In all those years, I probably never played more than a dozen games. But then, I started to play some online games out of boredom. After loosing and loosing and loosing... I got to the point where I found opponents of my skill level. And then I won. 

That win motivated me to play more. And while I lost as much as I won... I started to understand the game. Sure, I understood the rules... but I never had an appreciation of the synergy between pieces or the language of the game. 

Today, Chess is my most played game by far. While I don't log my plays... there hardly is a day that I don't play a game of chess or do some tactical problems. It truly is a wonderful game that has been play tested over centuries.

RATING: 9
Ezen kívül életem során még sok száz, sőt inkább több ezer partit játszottam. A régiek közül csak azt tudtam bekönyvelni, aminek a játszmalapja megvan. A szabályokat már 5 évesen tudtam, de csak 13 évesen kezdett érdekelni, akkor kezdtem el könyvekből tanulgatni (Apu egy ideig versenyszerűen sakkozott), és eljártam tanulgatni hivatásosok közé. Az utóbbi időben már inkább csak a neten (a felsoroltakon kívül kb. 3-400 parti), de régente versenyeken, és nyaranta Nagyapámmal is rengeteget játszottam.

Egy barátom mondta egy társasjáték után (Warcraft) reklamáló társának: "Ha olyan játékot akarsz, amiben nincs szerepe a szerencsének, menj el sakkozni:)". És milyen igaz. A sakk tisztán taktikai, stratégiai és logikai képességeket igényel. És legtöbbször a jobb nyer. Egyik kedvenc játékom. Bármikor bárkivel szívesen leülök sakkozni. Megunhatatlan.

RATING: 10
I will never get tired of Chess. I might get intimidated. I might forget my opening repertoire and have to rebuild my plans. I might even stop playing for years at a time. I will never lose that feeling of depth and color when studying a game by Tal or Fischer or Alekhine (my favorites).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Chess is a terrific game with a horrific flaw.  It is at its best among two equally skilled players and gets progressively worse as the difference in skill levels increases as there is zero luck to mix things up.

I enjoy that there is a narrative to every game if you know what to look for.

One of the best aspects of chess is that is so widely played and analyzed that if you choose to study it and look for material on it, you will find that there is an over abundance of materials ranging from books to videos and everything in between.

Chess definitely has the depth to be played and replayed over a lifetime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I used to love chess. I was in chess club in HS,etc. Then, realized that certain players just merely memorize moves like a robot. Played someone and they trashed me because I did "predictable" moves. Second game, I nearly won because I had no strategy, just  moved randomly while protecting each piece. That's "bad" chess. 5.

Update: I am playing regularly at lunch and moved from a "5" to a "7.5." The above criticism can still be true, but I am moving with a "randomized purpose" in my openings and it has helped break the mold.

RATING: N/A
Outstanding game!  Speed chess is addicting if playing with opponent's of the same skill level.  However, I no longer seek out chess opponents.  Currently I'm more interested in playing a variety of multi-player games, so I guess I am no longer addicted to Chess.   

I could literally play speed chess, Bughouse, or a variant form of chess (or Shogi) for hours at a time.  However, I am not interested in seeking out chess players.  However, I would love to play speed chess with gamers in my present circle of Euro/Wargamers.

The main downside to Chess and/or Bughouse is that I need the time pressure in order to have an awesome experience.

RATING: 6
[i]Posted: 7/20/04, Rated: 9[/i]

The game mechanics are sleek and refined after centuries of polish. Luck plays no part in this game at all.

[i]Chess[/i] is the perfect example of "what you get out of it is what you put into it."  I simply don't have the free time to spend learning "the openings" as I somehow feel obligated to spend. The last thing that I need from a game is guilt.

On the plus side, there will always be an avid [i]Chess[/i] following, and if you know where to look, you can always find a game.

[i]Updated: 8/1/05, Rated: 6[/i]

I'm dispensing with the guilt.  If this game were a true "9," then I would want to play it at every opportunity.  That simply is not the case.  I like to play [i]Chess,[/i] but there are many other games that I would reach for first.

RATING: 10
Dynamic pieces with unique movements make chess more interesting to me than other abstracts. The possibility for 'brilliancies' (or in my case, somewhat uncommon/unexpected but nice moves) make the game incredibly wonderful -- in many ways, art-like. Chess has fairly simple rules, yet incredible depth, and is enjoyable at many levels  -- a testament to its greatness. I enjoy chess most with other casual players (where memorization and over-analysis aren't big problems), but it's still hard to find opponents.  Thankfully this is one game I can have a great time playing alone (vs. the computer). A classic for all time, and rightly so. (2009-03)

RATING: 7.5
Timeless classic but requires players of comparable ability, it's only, but often, fatal flaw.

If marketed now it wouldn't have a hope in hell of reaching its status, but does that matter? Prefer to play players who are slightly better. Playing online is a great way to set up cheap accommodation for the global traveller ;-) Memories of one match in Kinlochleven will cheer me up for the rest of my life...

Ironically it was Knightmare Chess that rekindled my love for the basic game (and at the same time injected a welcome dose of light-hearted fun and complex but wacky strategies into something that is often taken a wee bit too seriously). I happily sit down with just about anyone for a match of Knightmare Chess, but the ideal chess partner is proving much harder to find.

RATING: 5
Tags: NoTier, Abstract, SpecialPowers

I used to be in a chess club when I was in school.  Back then I thought it was a great game (and I didn't know at all about any others except for things like Checkers, Life, Scrabble, etc).

Nowadays I think chess is okay in its own right, but I much much prefer some chaos with my chess, usually in the form of Knightmare Chess cards, and sometimes in the form of quick chess variants (Bughouse and Extinction to name a few).  I think I played chess out of my system when I was younger and in a chess club.

That said, I got a folding wooden chess board with small wooden chess pieces that's roomy enough to fit in both Knightmare chess decks.

Haba apparently has a very cute, tiny chess pocket chess set made out of wood.  It is probably a patch over the little plastic sets you can get here, but you couldn't take it in a plane/car.  Still, it looks very cute.

RATING: 8

With that mindset, I find that the game becomes really rich and interesting.

RATING: 6
Not bad, but I'm never "Yay, chess!"

Chess has one of my pet peeves of a game, and that's "when you start winning, you have the advantage".  You take down their bishop, now they have one less thing to defeat you with.  

So, I spend a lot of my time in this game defending myself looking for that perfect mistake-free move.  This is the game I find myself playing on my phone, a lot.

RATING: 10
Best game of pure skill of all time. The fact that it is not in the top 100 is ridiculous. I'm of the firm belief that most of the negative critique of this comes from people discouraged with the fact that they suck at it. Yes, if you suck you will get your ass handed to you by a superior player. Every single time. That can be frustrating, but that is sort of the point of a pure skill game. Some of the discrepancies in skill-level can be mitigated by playing speed chess with the better player getting less time on the clock, if you're so inclined (I am).

This game is not for casual gamers, and to enjoy the game you have to put time into it.

RATING: 9
The best simple two-player game. The strategy is extremely complicated, and building your fort is pretty satisfying.

That said, at a casual level it often comes down to who has memorized the best openings, or who makes the least stupid mistakes, rather than who has the better master plan. Allowing take-backs can help, but it's still a problem. The better player also wins most of the time, but if he messes around with strategies he's not used to it helps balance out the game until the better player only wins ~75% of the time.

RATING: 6
There is nothing intuitive about chess. Ostensibly, it is a wargame but really the level of abstraction means it has very little in common with modern wargames. Good players learn all known strategies by heart. It is a skill game - absolutely: there is no random element - in that you try to anticipate your opponent's strategy several turns ahead. All in all, being good at chess requires years of study which is partly the reason it is not a fun game: the learning curve is in the way.

RATING: 6
A great game ruined by a heavy past. Too much study has been put into this game, and it's cultural and historical weight make it seem a bigger deal than it actually is. If you don't play this well, you're seen as dumb, and if you play it well (or say that you enjoy playing it) you're "really smart". Bah, I hate silly shit like that. 

It's not really the game's fault that this has happened (can a game be actually blamed for anything?) but that doesn't make these un-inherent flaws cease to exist.

One game design flaw: the possibility of a tied match is very real. Sucks, considering a match can take a while (and take its toll on your mental energy).

I love chess puzzles, though.

03.04.2012
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Uhh, let's be serious folks!  

This is the granddaddy of strategy games.  There are HUNDREDS of books to help people, tournaments, etc.  If you are a chess player you can go to almost any city and find players.  

Even a king and three pawns vs. a king and 2 pawns is an unbelievably complex game.

Of course, if you win or lose, its just you and the opponent.  Will any other game be there 100 years from now?  I assure you chess will.  Even bridge is fading, but chess is going strong!

If you find a 'chessplayer', they will tell you there just isn't anything else out there.

Only only a slightly better than average tournament player, but even for a player of my rather mediocre strength, there is a beauty here that no other game seems to have.  I've been playing for 30 years and I will never stop.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
I dislike abstract games... especially ones like Chess where many moves (e.g. opening strategies) are scripted.  Studying and memorizing the moves and counter-moves is not fun for me.  I like more free-form games with at least a little luck.  Also, Chess is one of those games (like Scrabble) where it is best to play against someone near the same skill level as yourself... because runaway leader games are not fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
50 plays:

Obviously, Chess's nearly endless depth is its most powerful feature, and it's hard to balance that with an evaluation of its appeal for casual players.

With that said, I think one of the game's great aspects of accessibility to a casual player is that while there are many possible moves at any one time, there are often only a handful that aren't obviously mistakes, which lightens the experience and lessons analysis paralysis. 

Still, requiring a timer for games to not feel agonizing and sluggish reflects a basic flaw in the game. (Compare to Poker or Backgammon, for example, which are turn-based and have many possibilities but don't require timers.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Briefly took interest in this a a kid.  Pretty dull now.  I don't want to expend years of my life memorizing what others already figured out, just so I can start to be moderately competitive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I own this as part of a 12-game travel set with miniature magnetized pieces, also includes checkers, backgammon, chinese checkers, snakes and ladders, pahrcheesi, tic tac toe, and several games I have never played, 9 men's morris, kono, horserace, horseshoe, and star. 

I consider chess to be THE strategy game. How many other games have been studied in as much detail as this one, and have so many different names for opening moves, for instance? Why this game is rated so low is a mystery to me. It is a challenging game, but that's no reason to give it a really low score. I'm voting a 10 when I figure out how to vote for games.

RATING: 7.2
The ultimate classic.  

Everyone should play now and then just to improve planning,strategy, and being able to see how things can lay out in the future.  The big thing with this game is that based on playing and ranking it can the win can become way to predictable.  It can be disappinting that you simply are unable to make a showing against the highly skilled.

If you have a person equal in skill there may not be a better two person game.

I played with my dad as a kid and in my 20s I read a ton of books and improved on my computer etc. This game is playable now on lots of internet venues making it more accessible than ever.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RULES: **** - The rules of the game are fairly simple, however, there is some obscure, let's not fear the word, crap, which may confuse new gamers and which actually just doesn't add much to the game at all. However, after you manage to teach people how the god-damn en passant works, the rest is easy going.
STRATEGY: *** - While there is a single goal that you must achieve, chess does offer several paths to it and several playing types you could apply. While this game is definitely more of a tactic type, opening moves may dictate a very swift game with lots of casualties and huge combinations involving lots of pieces or a long and difficult defensive grind, where every move feels like a puzzle to solve.
TACTICS: **** - Chess offer quite a few tactical decisions for a player each turn since there are multiple types of units which are best used in different contexts of the battle, hence there is always a nail-biting search for that perfect move that would counter opponents threats and make some of your own.
LUCK: ***** - This is a zero-luck game, meaning that absolutely everything depends on the skill level of the players. While I find it personally to be a huge advantage, there is a disadvantage that the player who is less skilled will be likely demolished very quick, since the possible skill margin to have an equal game of chess is arguably too little.
PLAYER INTERACTION: ***** - Every move made by your opponent can significantly alter your own plans, thus chess is really one of the best games where the battle between players' minds can be felt.
REPLAYABILITY: ****
THEME: * - Even though it is an abstract modeled after medieval warfare, it is still an abstract. Since I haven't seen towers moving around the battlefield, I see chess more of a huge puzzle on 8x8 grid than a battle between two armies.
BALANCE: ***** -  The sides do play a little bit differently because of the turn-by-turn nature of the game, since white gets a little momentum to attack and black has to defend, but I really don't find black any less likely to win.
DOWNTIME: ** - In this game it is OK to wait whole minutes pondering your next move. Seriously. You have been warned - analysis paralysis is the standard behavior when you play Chess. Thanks for the genius who invented chess clock.
ACCESSIBILITY: ** - This is a difficult one. Normally, finding someone who can play this game is fairly easy. The problems start if you want to play with someone skilled, since the game is just too unforgiving for a rookie, especially if you don't devote time to study chess and don't memorize the huge bunch of default openings.

RATING: 5
I have a love/hate relationship with chess and right now:

Meh....

I used to play tournaments years ago, but have not done so since 1998.  From about 1988-98 I played a lot of chess :)  Now, I'm on to other games, but I still play a game or two (mostly blitz) from time to time.  Classic game which teaches so much in so little time.  Since I've started recording games on the geek: 1660-1088=102.  
 

Update: finally played a tournament for the first time this year (2011) since 1998.  Looking forward to getting back into competition.  :)

Return to tournament play has been good although I did sink down in rating :shake: but broke even for 2011 going +4-4=1 for the year.  :)

2012 has started out well but had a weak finish.  So the year ended with me going +12-11=4 in tournament play.  Cracked 1500 level for the first time rating wise!!! :cool:  :D  Very happy about that!  The year ended badly with two disastrous tournaments.  I won only 1 game in my last 9 :what: :gulp:  Hopefully 2013 will be better.  :)

2013 is off to a terrific start!  I finished second in the 1400-1499 group in the U1700 section of the Land of the Sky XXVI tournament in Asheville, NC.  I also finished second in the U1800 section for the Saturday morning blitz tournament.  As a result, I now have my highest rating ever at 1516! :) Finished the Pittsburgh Open with my new highest rating ever of 1589 and another tie for 2nd in my class.  I didn't play another tournament this year but I did well and hope for some tournaments in 2014.  So I finished 2013 +9-7=3.

First tournament of 2016 was blitz tournament at the VA Closed.  First play since 2013 resulted in a bad showing of 3/8.
So far for 2016 +3-5.

RATING: 8
I used to love chess and played it competitively in many local tournaments while in high school and early college. I still have a small library of chess books. Chess is a hugely deep game. As I progressed in my skill level I found a deeper appreciation for the game. I have played 5 minute blitz games along with marathon 5 hour tournment games. I eventually gave up competitive play to focus on my studies and now it is disappointing for me to play at such a lower level than I once did. At higher levels chess suffers from having to memorize various openings, but this is hardly a problem for the beginner. Because chess is purely skill-based with no luck fator, a game of chess between two vastly different skilled players is usually a far gone conclusion and can be very boring. When I have more time I hope to pick chess up again as I met many great people and had lots of fun playing in chess clubs and tournaments. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love playing Chess for several reasons.  The first seems strange, but the game can take months.  I love that I can have a heavy game which takes up little to no space (the developed notation systems make it easy to recreate the board).  One thing I hate is playing a heavy war game which will take days (or weeks) to resolve and having to leave the game set up with hundreds of counters knowing that someone's cat will come up and eat/move a piece.  And god forbid if someone sneezes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Certainly the king of all games.  I wish I was better and had fewer gaming interests so I could give it the attention it deserves.  I've played more Chess, by far, than any other game.I can understand why people don't like Chess: it's complex, painful, rewards repeated play, and the better player will nearly always win. Playing well requires attention and thought--a lot of attention and thought. What I don't understand are all of the ignorant comments about the game on BGG, such as the need memorize openings (not true until you're rated in the upper 1000's or maybe even 2000's; intermediate players will not be able to exploit an opening advantage against  a player who better understands basic tactics and mid-game strategic advantages) or complaints about White's first-move advantage (which is true only once you're good enough to be able to exploit it, which I doubt many BGGer's are; if you're that concerned about the first-move advantage, play Blitz, it vanishes). I get especially annoyed by the latter complaint since few, if any, of the themeless and pallid Euro's that many users are so enamored with would stand up to even a 1/10th of the scrutiny Chess has undergone over the last couple of centuries. Give me a break. 

While it is true that you can't get beyond a fairly basic level without some study, the game's difficulty is overstated. A basic primer on tactics (via a beginner's book and maybe the Chess Tactics Server) will vastly improve your play without any major time commitments (excepting the need to play as much as possible, which once Chess gets it hooks in you, will naturally happen anyway).

All that said, I'm still not so great at Chess and I especially suck at blitz games. Blitz (or bullet or lightening or anything shorter than 30 minutes) is an entirely different game that I haven't even begun to get a handle on. 

Anyway, I'm gushing. I will never get sick of Chess, and to really make clear how much I like the game I should down-grade every other game I've played by .5. I love gaming. Wargames, Euro's, RPG's, whatever, but nothing beats Chess for me. A game that I love with a passion and will always play, despite being pretty much not so good at it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Very popular in the West. I used to be deeply fascinated with this game, until I decided to look properly into the world of ancient Chess variants from Asia (Shogi from Japan and Xiangqi from China, for instance).

I still enjoy the occasional game. I have played in several unofficial tournaments and have never been rated, although I once had a theoretical draw against an 1800 ELO player in the endgame which I threw away, for whatever it's worth. Although weak compared to a lot of club players, I am strong enough to virtually always defeat a casual player.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Well, my apartment is decorated with chess sets I've collected from around the world.  One from Chile (the indiginous versus the conquistadors), one from Italy, a marble set with its own stand (where my chess clock sits), and a glass set from Asia.

You really can't knock this game because it's so widespread.  It's everywhere for a reason.  The only reason I knock this game down a point is because for some it is more than a game - and the fun factor begins to disappear when it becomes that for you.  The openings have been overanalyzed, and I don't appreciate that because the real heart of chess is the middle and ending, where real talent comes into play over memorized theoretical positions.

When I lived in Amsterdam, I spent several days a weeks watching masters and the occasional grandmaster play in arenas and in small chess clubs.  I was amazed to simply watch their skill at work.  However, at the same time, I knew I never wanted to get to where they were, because the upkeep required to stay that skilled could better be spent on things in this life that have more meaning and impact.  I play chess for community and sharpening the mind, not for isolation.  But it remains one of the greatest games ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1.00001
I feel it is simply my responsibility as a legitimate game designer and someone who understands and appreciates games on a higher level than the swaths of people who have haphazardly rated it a ten despite having little to no familiarity with other games. I could go on a lengthy diatribe about its various shortcomings but I wont. New games are better. Game design is a science and like any science it become more refined over time. If the current market doesn't reflect this then it reflects only on the lack of refinement of popular designers. Oh and Chess is a game from the dark ages. Its time to move on.

RATING: 5
I played a LOT of chess in my high school days. Literally, almost daily. I attended several tournaments and established a USCF rating. 

I still enjoy abstracts....but I find my interest in a game of chess to just be a very rare occurrence. I still respect the game. I just don't find myself that interested in sitting and analyzing the board for so long. I'd rather play a shorter 2p abstract (like the Gipf games) or a complex 2p wargame (like Paths of Glory). If someone very interested in chess wanted to play, I suppose I could be talked into it. But I'd probably be scheming how to introduce them to Euros. I don't even currently own a chess set.

When I DID play regularly, I tended to use a Queen's Gambit opening (since opponents, at least at the high school level, seemed less comfortable defending it) and a variant of the Sicilian Defense (for about the same reason). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have nothing to say that hasn't been said better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An overly studied abstract strategy game which is very good, but which is very hard to find similarly skilled opponents for. I think that I prefer this slightly to Go based on the shorter play time, but I have to break down and say that Go still draws me back more, and is the game I have greater respect for. If I was sitting in a coffee house and someone asked me to play a game I will usually sit down and enjoy myself, but the game as such doesn't compel me unless I'm playing against someone who is of roughly equal skill level to me. It's too studied by too many people in North America which makes finding an equally skilled opponent extremely difficult and there is no handicapping feature ala Go. The limitations on the board also feel stifling to me at this point, again, not because the game as such is limited in any sense, but because it has been studied to such a degree that even casually hardcore Chess players know all manner of openings and such which robs the creativity that I look for in games. I know that Go, which I keep comparing this to (as I consider those two games vying for the title of THE abstract strategy game) can have similar issues, but they just don't feel as real here in NA because Go is still a relatively underground phenomenon which means it is very easy for a bad player (me) to find equal foes than it is for me as an above average bad Chess player to find equal foes...if that makes sense to anyone but me. Still, I do like the game as such, I just have trouble finding opponents who make it enjoyable enough for me to rate it higher than 6.

RATING: 6
I played this game a lot as a kid. As you can imagine, it doesn't get much play now. Recently I have played a couple team games. This variant calls for two team members to play opposite colors. When a piece is taken from your opponent, you give the piece to your teammate, who can then place it anywhere on his board. We use a timer to make the games fast. The randomness this variant added was surprisingly fun.

RATING: 7
A great game especially when you can repeatedly play an opponent who is equally skilled as (or preferably slightly better than) yourself. Because there is no luck (except who is white), differences in playing ability often are magnified (the main reason it is not a 10- also I rarely play 2 player games except with my wife). I learned by getting whipped by my father and Nana until I improved to the point where I rarely lost. Now I run school Chess Clubs and enjoy playing the best students and teaching the newer players a little.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The oldest one, and said to be the hardest one. Whole generations have been playing and developing its rules. This game is so beautiful being both simple end extremely complex that it's hard to believe that it's man-designed. 

Completely luckless - it's all about skill and (even more important) sheer will of winning.

It helps improving things like memory and logical thinking incredibly well - simply due to its abstraction level and due to how things mentioned above are required.

Unfortunately, because of reasons mentioned above, it will be always underestimated, just like the differences in "skills" will be naturally huge at all times. Luckily, the one who once tried and liked it, will always want to come back for "another game of chess".

You may not agree with that, but it's simply the best board game ever. Period.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
I'm a recovering `chess team' player. Chess serves as my benchmark for the 6.9 abstracts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I played chess in primary school because that's what smart kids did. However, I liked the puzzle aspect of chess more than I did the game itself. I was never able to fathom nor appreciate the finer points of chess strategy (strength of 2 bisshops are stronger than one bisshop and a knight, or that a rook and a bishop are more powerful than a queen) and so abandoned the game when there were no more puzzles left for me to solve. The lack of players equal in my pitiful level, a pocket computer which beats me effortlessly, and the superduper analyses in extremis surrounding professionals have turned me off. It is a timeless classic, but in order to play interesting games I'd need to invest more time than I can and am willing to spare. I [i]much[/i] prefer the 'simplicity' of go which at least cuts down on the amount of types of playing pieces, and can be scaled down to smaller boards instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Unpopular opinion: chess is less interesting than obscure or historical variants, because of AIs and deeply mapped opening theory. Try Hiashatar, or less exotic Makruk-style games. Of course, many historical variants are just plain terrible... but while I have studied "pure" chess I now regard other games as more lively, as a next frontier of sorts. Also, variants on bigger boards can be slavish and crude, but also tasteful if done well, as in Hiashatar.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't really understand why people who really like games don't enjoy this.  I would guess that partially it is because they have not played competitevly.  There is nothing better than sitting across from someone and trying to destroy their ego...

But really the main complaint seems to be that chess has been studied to death.  Yeah?  So what?  There is still not an answer to the question of, what is the best move?  There is just so much room for variety in chess.  If you get bored sitting for long periods, a chess clock set at 10 minutes can make for a quick brain-bending exercise.  In the mood for a casual game that you can get up from and eat dinner and come back to and still enjoy?  Try chess...

[c]
Production  -> N/A - depends
Fun         -> :star::star::nostar::nostar:
Play Desire -> :star::star::star::star:
Theme       -> :star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Down Time   -> :star::star::star::star:
[/c]

Fun here really depends on whether I am doing well.  Sometimes really fun, sometimes not so much.

Sure there is down time in chess, but you had better spend your time thinking.  And if you don't like that play blitz with a clock, that will pretty much end that complaint.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Discovered the joys of Chess at the ripe old age of 27.  I'm painfully, humiliatingly bad at it, but I can't get enough.  

As much as I hate to give a game this power, Chess can make or ruin an entire day.  That's as close to criticism as I can give.


UPDATE:  The more I play, the more I adore this hoary old game.  It's not the only game I rate a 10, but Chess is my (second) favorite by a huge margin. 

"Painfully, humiliatingly bad" no longer describes me, though I'm far from what would be considered "good" in the Chess world.  I'm actually pretty happy with where I am and would be comfortable staying at this level, which is still well within the realm of "casual" play.  

The bit I wrote before about Chess being able to ruin my day is still somewhat true.  I don't mind losing, that's not the problem, and neither do I beat myself up too much when I blunder.  I mostly play correspondence Chess, and sometimes I'll spend an inordinate amount of time working through the possibilities of a position, treating the game as seriously as if I were responsible for actual living troops on a battlefield.  And if I'm in an uncertain situation, I have a hard time not thinking about it while I wait for my opponent's response.  It's an enjoyable form of stress, but it does tend to consume me when I get locked into that mindset.

---
Update (2013):  I've sort of burned myself out for the time being.  Not just Western Chess but Shogi and Xiangqi as well.  I'm not terribly sure why this is, though I [i]suppose[/i] it might have something to do with a recent string of defeats.  My increasing fascination with Dameo and Amazons also probably shares some of the blame.

Update (2016): For the past few years Chess (and to a  lesser extent backgammon) are practically the only board game I play.  I burned myself out on long correspondence games, but have fallen hard for Blitz.  Other than when relatives visit, I really don't have anyone to play board games with, but Online Blitz fits perfectly into my lifestyle, and I can usually squeak in a game or two per day (and defeats no longer bother me at all; I have, in fact, become quite an expert at losing).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

RATING: 6.75
Excellent game of strategy.  My eldest really likes Chess so I play it often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The all-time most brilliant abstract strategy game (and with the thousands and thousands of variants out there, it's hard to get bored with it).  The ultimate problem though: it's designed as a HEAVY thinking game which means games are only remotely entertaining or challenging when you're paired with someone who's right around your same level of skill.  Newbie players go down way too easy (which frustrates them into not liking Chess) and more thoughtful players will wipe the floor with your butt. So, I recommend looking for variants which even out the playing field a bit.  Fun variants like Knightmare Chess (don't bother with the overpriced cards, just make up your own), or Juggernaut Chess can ease the massive amount of strategy.  With all its faults, though, Chess really is the ultimate test of wits between expert players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Top 5 all time, sure. Played tons since I was a kid - plenty of blitz, plenty at freechess and chessclub. Read books, studied tactics, openings, and endgames.

Its certainly frustrating that there's always someone out there who is studying their book deeper than you are, and they'll follow the script longer than you and have that slight edge.

It was more fun when I wasn't trying to remember what I think I should know, and was just playing. I guess that's why I end up playing fast games, to hopefully mitigate the study aspect and bring back the excitement and joy of the game.

Chess is also a game that requires similarly matched opponents, so I can't rate it a 10 ... until my kids start beating me - then we'll see. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The timeless king and queen of games! :)

A large part of my gaming roots lies in Chess: I have been playing competitive chess for more than 25 years now - mostly in my youth (including large international opens), but recently I at least still play one or two league games per year for my old team. Actually, in the current season I have started to play a bit more again.

Chess is the only base game I rate with a straight 10 and consequently, it also holds the top spot in my Top 10. At least the latter seems unlikely to change in the foreseeable future, so the other games pretty much only compete for 2nd place.

One important reason I hold Chess so dear is its universal recognition around the world. It is a science of its own with so many professional players and many other people who make their living around chess (for instance as trainers or authors). I love the level of analysis that comes with this, the immense wealth of chess literature and software.
This is so much the game of games that it has stopped being "just a game" long ago. I personally mainly view it as a competitive form of mental sport and also as a form of art. I can find great beauty in a masterpiece of chess.

RATING: 6
Components: I prefer the more abstract representations of the pieces to those portraying characters of some sort. Assuming heavy pieces on a wooden board, I find Chess to be a handsome game.

Experience: I have a chip on my shoulder about this game: because of its popularity, I'm intimidated and discouraged by the amount of thought that has already gone into strategic play. There's nothing for me to discover, and mostly I'll just make bone-headed moves. Like a handful of other popular games (Go, Scrabble, Checkers), it would be more efficient to study how to play well than to learn by playing.

When I'm pitted against someone with comparable skill, it's a fun puzzle to solve. Each move, offensive or defensive, part of a tight machine, where each component serves a purpose and nothing shifts position without consequence.

First Played: 2013-11-29
Last Played: 2016-03-15
Plays (3):
2 players: 3
vs. robot: 10 (not included in total)

RATING: 3
Hard to put a number to. This is THE most anylyzed game ever. Meaning that your true ability in the game comes down to your knowledge of published Chess info. So it's no longer a game, but a test of accumulated Chess facts and ideas. Good humans and computers essentially play the game the same way.

Plus, if it were invented today it would just be a very ho-hum abstract, with nothing to differentiate it from more interesting, and perhaps even deeper, abstracts. Like Monopoly, this game only survives due to inertia and gravity.

RATING: 1
Chess would be a good game if there wasn't so many bloody books and articles written about how to play!  You can't just sit down with someone and play chess, 'cos chances are that they know a pile of 'opening gambits' and just thrash you at it.  You can't beat them by being clever or witty, you need to read books about chess!  Chess has ceased to be a game, it's just a contest about how much stuff you can remember about how to counter opening moves etc.  If only none of the literature about chess exested, I would probably feel inclinded to rate is 7 or 8 out of 10.

RATING: 4

If there were a widely employed handicapping system like in Go, I'd enjoy it more. As is, playing against a superior player will almost never see a surprise win and the game can feel almost like an exercise in futility.

Fun when learning and playing against others of roughly equal skill.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The ULTIMATE and DEFINITIVE boardgame!

(see bottom line for more details on this subject)
 
The inclusion of this game in my rating list is somehow artificial because it introduces a logarithm scale gap for the 2nd ranked, otherwise that game would score something like 1 (even though beeing also a brilliant game), turning the elaboration of this rating list a pointless task.
The setup is always the same and requires less than half a minute to achieve.
Nothing more than 32 pieces and 64 squares provide the scenary for an endless number of games of infinite variability, where everything is at sight all the time and there´s no absolut room for chance, meaning that the outcome is the direct result of the interation between your actions and those of your opponent.
The rules can be thaugth in less than 10 minutes but the learning curve is virtually infinite, beeing usual to only begin taking full pleasure of the game´s potencial after several months of practice, several times a week (this is perhaps it´s  only major drawback).
The progression in the game skill is the result of a combination englobing motivation, practice, study and talent, by that order.
By this same reason, there is no chance a lesser skilled player can put up a fight to a much higher skilled player, and this is usually subject of some criticism but, then again, is not the persue of perfection a natural desire of humans?! Does not happen the same when training sports, music or arts?! Sure it happens, and that´s the reason why chess is also a bit of a sport, a bit of an art and a bit of a science.
Not just through the global strategy, but even sometimes just through the mere visualization of a set of moves, it is possible to outline the main features of a player´s personality, since, over a chess board, all of one`s fears, all of one`s courage, all of one`s wisdom, all of one`s stamina, all of one`s knowledge, all of one`s arrogance, etc, come to life in flying colors. 
That´s how, just through a couple of games between two average (or better) players it´s possible to perceive how each of them thinks and feels, not just like a player, but also like an individual. 
Chess has its rules settled down for the last 500 years, however, before that period , there were (at least) another 10 centuries in which those rules were beeing tuned to optimization and balance. 
The result was a mechanism of perfection, a masterpiece capable of produce jewels of beauty and aesthetic pleasure in which the players function like no more than pieces of a greater show, even though are their brains, their imagination and their creativity the source behind all what´s visible.     
I own more than 30 different chess sets, have been playing it for 30 years now and have done, for sure, more than 10 000 games until this point.
I play chess by heart, i play it blinfold, i play it whenever and wherever someone is looking for a game.
Perhaps was the will to escape the "matrix" of a chess board that lead me into the world of modern boardgames!...

Bottom line: I own a game of Go and (kind of) know the rules, but never played a single game. From what i read and ear, is perhaps the only game that could (i underline "could") go beyond chess.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
- Gameplay and replayability: 3/3. Thoroughly enjoyable and competitive game that never gets boring. The only thing I regret is that computer opponents are too strong, making it very frustrating to play against. Even grandmasters have a hard time beating computers, giving somewhat the feeling that the game is "solved".

- Luck factor: 3/3. No randomness involved, only pure strategy.

- Duration: 3/3. One game takes approximately half an hour to play.

- Player range: 1/3. 2 players only.

- Theme and looks: 2/3. There is no theme and even expensive Chess sets are not that beautiful in my opinion. However, given the long history of the game, a chess board is classy and breathes nostalgia. 

- Set up/clean up time: 3/3. Less than 5 minutes.

- Learning curve: 2/3. The rules can be explained in 10 minutes. 

- Durability: 3/3. A good chess set will last forever.

- Portability: 3/3. If you buy a travel chess game, you get maximum portability.

- Summary: Lots of strategy and replayability for 2 players. Best short game I've played so far.

I'd rather play many other strategy games.

RATING: 10

Still have over 50 trophies on the mantel -- one mine, three father-son, the rest our now-teenager's, who I don't think even remembers his chess years much.

RATING: 9.1
Chess is not a well designed or easy to understand game, like Hex or even Go. It was designed "by committee" over hundreds of years. Once you have internalised the rules, however, you are privy to the entire history of this wonderful pastime, the toils and struggles of so many to understand and teach the game, an absolute litany of resources, including expert computer opponents awaits anyone trying to master this game of abstract strategy. The cultural and intellectual legacy and international community of chess is what makes it great, despite its very large first player advantage, its arcane and illogical rules and its tendency to be extremely drawish at high levels. I learned it as a child and I still enjoy learning.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
You may be asking why did I rate Chess, the venerated game of kings, so low?

Time commitment. Beyond learning the basics of chess (how pieces move, board position, etc), chess requires an absolutely ludicrous amount of time to play with any proficiency. The worst part, and the part that breaks my heart, is that this is not through an fault of the game but though its widespread success and acceptance. There are so many people who play chess, who study it, who participate in tournaments, and so on. Because chess is a game purely based on the skill, the better player will pretty much always win. That's fine, that's balanced, but it's not fun if you're the unskilled player. Frankly, it's not much fun if you're the skilled player either. It's only matches of equal ability that really brings out the tension of the game. Such matches are perhaps easier to find in the digital age, but within a home or group a friends, not so much.

Don't get me wrong, Chess is an absolute classic and a wonderful game. I just don't want to spend thousands of hours on one game just to still be a novice at it.

RATING: 5.5
It's a classic game, probably deserving of a higher rating. But it has been so extensively studied that one has no chance of playing it well unless he is prepared to spend months immersed in books about chess, memorizing play sequences.  And I don't want to do that. It also suffers from repetitive opening sequences, which tend to be kind of boring, and it feels very crowded, with so many pieces on such a small board. I much prefer Shuuro, since I believe it fixes almost everything I find annoying in Chess, and especially Arimaa, which is not really that similar to Chess, but somehow occupies the same niche of brain stimulation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Chess will still be played a thousand years from now, when other games on BGG will have come and gone.  

Chess is a game that can be bought with plastic pieces and a cardboard board for a few dollars, or one can buy very expensive sets made out of material like marble.  It can be found everywhere.

Chess has very few rules to learn, and is easy to set up.

A pure test of skill.  Chess can be a "heavy game" since it can take a great deal of play, study, and thinking to become good at it, but you can be as competitive or recreational as you want to be.

I am not great at it, but I know I am playing a great game every time I pull it out.  

How many other games on BGG have thousands of books and articles written about them.  This game can only be a ten (10).

The slow start / fixed patterns ...

The queen. Too important for a single piece.

The crowded board. Half of the squares is occupied!

RATING: 8.5
Chess is a classic game.

I used to play Chess all the time in primary and high school. I rarely play Chess today. I guess I out grown it. Or maybe today, I have access to more interesting games.

By having not played a lot over the last couple of years, it did not help with my game. I am a bit rusted. It played a few games in last couple of years and I didn't win that much. Chess needs to be played on a regular basis in order to stay sharp and focus on the game you play.

Chess is a 2 player game. I rarely play 2 player games today. It`s the reason why I don`t have that many 2 player games in my collection.

I own the Lord of the Rings: Fellowship of the Ring chess set and played with it a few times. It is very nice chess set. 

I just might get the Return of the King version. I don't know yet. Is it really worth having two chess sets of Lord of the Rings ? The pieces are a different characters and color.

One might think one chess set is enough, but Lord of the Rings is...well Lord of the Rings!

I might really consider it if my games played of Chess increases.

Got as a gift 3-1 Chess, Checkers, Backgammon set made in glass.

2 plays since recording games played.

RATING: 4
I'm not sure Chess is fun.  Go to chess.com, look at the tournament pics, do they look like they're having fun or sitting on the toilet?  I find people take this game way too seriously or else are afraid of it.  Nowadays, I feel it takes too long to finish (isn't chess why game clocks were invented?), I've always detested the high AP in my opponents, and that one wrong move can cost the game after an hour, hour and a half.  More worringly, is the frequency games can end in unsatisfying stalemates.  The concept though that you have to intentionally sacrifice certain pieces in order to progress is intriguing, but perhaps more of a play style.

Look, I realise this is 600 year old game and I get its mystique, but it's much overrated based on nostalgia or some sort of game cum mental puzzle, and seemingly more of a spatial, IQ gladitorial contest for fellow braniacs.  But as a game that should be fun?  It doesn't really hold-up and I don't think many people, myself included, really get that much enjoyment out of playing it, decryingt that they moved their finger  off, or waiting for their go, when compared to everything else sitting on our shelf, harddrive or cloud we could otherwise be playing instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A classic abstract strategy game, worthy of a high rating, but the setting needs to be right to play it, and other games tend to be pulled out quicker.  Some of the chess variants like suicide and atomic are also fun, as is internet blitz chess, or face to face blitz with a [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/425859]digital chess clock[/url].

Also enjoyable are:
[gameid=12608] - also known as Fischer Random Chess, and levels the playing field for people not as familiar with all the standard openings.
[gameid=14188] - A partnership chess game where the pieces you capture can be placed by your partner on his board.  Chaotic, crazy, fast, and fun - less "serious" than regular chess.  Two chess clocks are needed for OTB play, but the best online play for free is at www.freechess.org, with each team usually having either 3 or 5 minutes total.
[gameid=95915] - Like bughouse for two players
[url=http://www.chessvariants.org/link2.dir/srchess.html][i]Stanley Random Chess[/i][/url] - a modern classic played at schemingmind.com
There are many other possible chess variants (see [url=http://chessvariants.com]chessvariants.com[/url]), I enjoy Atomic Chess and many others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
All time classic and one of the best games ever invented.
I will admit it shortcomings, it only is good with opponents that are of equal ability. I never took the time to really remember any openings, and would be crushed by a ranked player for sure. Still, this is fun when playing regular players, pure strategy, no luck at all. I can't say anything bad about it, other than it has been over-analyized by humans. It, IMO, deserves a 10.

RATING: 7
My rating is based more on the fact that Chess is a game that hardly scales.  I mean the enjoyment is solely based on how equally skilled the players are; if one player is more experienced and skilled, he will not get much out of beating his opponent.  It does make for a learning experience but the enjoyment turns into masochism if you are consistently beaten by better players.  Having been in that position (being beaten) for a long time, I can appreciate that this is one of the better games, but for entertainment there are lots of games that can pit better players against less skilled ones and still give a fighting chance to all involved.

RATING: 8.7
2016
====

Although Chess is no longer my favorite abstract game, I've spent so much time at a Chess board in my life that I'll admit a level of deep nostalgia still lingers. In addition to nostalgia, Chess is the only board game officially sanctioned and taught in my sons' school. Therefore, they and I play an awful lot of Chess games during any given year. Many of our games are teaching games though so I rarely log them. Even still, I enjoy these times and "quality time" so I suppose another layer of nostalgia is being added to my personal Chess history.

2014
====

My logged plays do not match, by a few orders of magnitude, the number of games I've played in my time.  This was really my first board game love and will always have a special place in my heart.

RATING: 6
Not sure how to rate chess.  It is truly a great, great game.  Every once in a while, I get the bug to study it a bit.  Then I play some crappy chess program set to 'moron' difficulty, lose horribly, and put it aside again for a few years.  I gave it a 6 because I just don't have much motivation to play.  I will never do this game justice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's impossible for me to rate this accurately.  I feel it's a classic game but I have little desire to play it anymore.  People get stuck in the muddy middle where they're better than the few folks they have to play it with but are no match for the "Lifers" who live, eat, and breath Chess study. 

Those folks make the game less enjoyable as it ceases being a game and more some sort of evangelical event.

The same sort of folks have been ruining other games for years (Scrabble), so...the best advice is to play it a handful of times with people you know and will enjoy the company with--and then move on.

I would have to be dragged into a game of this with someone I did not know.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.847
Chess is enjoyable; but not socially!  And I have never really learnt any opening moves (nor have the desire), and so will always be destined to lose to a person who does. Yet, chess is a board game where there can be these tiny moments of beauty rarely experienced in ther games.  Internet postcard chess I now find is far more fun than a face to face brain burn.  On occasion I enjoy the deep thinking over a chess board, but the main purpose of a game meeting should be the social company - hence will pull out a Eurogame.  An enjoyable game if you manage to find someone at your level to play postcard chess (rating 7), but as a social game, It's a 3.  Therefore, average rating is 5) (11/12/08). UPDATE: I have softened a bit with my assessment, as I have had a number of good games with my son.  Chess is the Beatles White Album of games, just enjoy this game with its amazing history (Rating: 7.847, Sept 16).

I'll just keep to go for that 'abstract strategy grand traditional awe-inspiring' game itch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Kids game whose only appeal is that it was invented long ago before there were better (or pretty much any other) games.  As such it was studied to death and people think it is somehow deeper than modern games.  Had Puerto Rico or Settlers of Cataan been invented in 100AD no one would ever have heard of Chess.  Game is a brain locker, takes too long, provides no chance for beginners to win, has no theme.  Only reason this is not a 1 is since everyone knows how to play it, you can always play a game.  The winner is usually determined before the game starts, based on the players skill (and this from someone that would probably beat 95% of the people in the world if I played them).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the king of the games.  I'd rank it up there with Go and GIPF.  If only Chess started with a "G", then we could have the three Gs!  Anyway, I was raised on this game, suffer analysis paralysis often, and rarely play it anymore because of lack of opponents and frustration.  A classic that can never be dethroned, whatever way emotions are running.

Each time I play hoping that one day I will stare at the board and go, "Ah ha!  I finally figured this damn game out..."  But until then, I'm at the mercy of anyone who knows what they're doing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Where it all begins- usually as a kid. And it's often either hated or loved from the start. Chess is strategy stripped down to bare essentials, with no need for theme, just an arena where 2 minds can clash. I played since the age of 8 and slowed down in my early teens. It's not played as much any longer, except with my daughter or wife at times --- or vs my iphone ap. But it's still appreciated. Like it or not, it was, is, & will always be a classic destined to outlast almost any game listed on the Geek (save maybe for 'Go'- another classic). It's more stressful than many games and the only way, as I see it, to get the most out of Chess is when 2 opponents are of relatively equal ability (which is when it shines). If not, then it's a tough experience for the loser. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I think of this as the perfect game, as far as abstracts go. It's very draining and I really only play several times a year, but it is always glorious. I've never become disinterested in chess, it always retains it's charm. I love how the game progresses, I love putting people in/being put in predicaments, I love how each move can pry your brain, I love the surprise of a move you hadn't considered. There's nothing like the satisfaction of an brilliant move, nothing like the devastation of being on the other end. Chess is beautiful.

RATING: 10

There is Chess.  Then all other games.

He didn't show me too much offense and that's where I lack and need improvement.  My wife and I play occasionally and my son is getting better each time we play.

RATING: 8
[Original comment] How can I not rate chess highly? It is the game from which all other challenging games stem (in my opinion), but not one I want to play everyday.

May 2009 -- I rarely play any 2-player games these days, and Chess isn't high on the list to use my time in that way. Still, I have to say that it is one of the greatest games ever invented.

2012 March -- I have begun playing chess again, with my son-in-law and my grandson via our iPhones. I am not logging the plays here, but I am enjoying playing the game again.

2013-November:  My son-in-law and I continue to have a chess game going on our iPhones constantly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.02
Chess is the ultimate deterministic strategy game. Not only is it easy to learn, it provides a virtually infinite number of possible end-game states as far as the human mind can understand them. Even though chess is a solved game, the fact that there is no randomness (but for the choice of white and black) means there is always a stochastically optimum move. However, playing against any given player may require adaptation because the stochasticity changes with the playstyle of the opponent. Easy to learn, but never simplistic.

RATING: 9
Chess is really the game that I blame for my descent into the war gaming world. I remember when I learned it as a child I wanted to get good. That right there is a major flaw because as the rules are simple enough but the weight of the pure strategy of the game is super deep. I have wasted more time reading books on chess than I have at playing almost any other game. I have played chess the most and my son became truly a good chess player. While I can play almost anytime I find the randomness of true war games more fun than a pure strategy game like chess. Still chess is one of the games that cross cultural and language barriers and for that I believe chess will remain for some generations to come a true classic.

RATING: N/A
I can't presume to rate Chess.  It's a different game depending on the level at which you're playing.  I find the pieces and board elegant and beautiful (can't stand "theme" sets) and both the tactics and strategy fascinating and metaphorically applicable to real life.  However, at the tournament level, which I dabbled in, it becomes a game of rote memorization.  Did you study the Exchange Variation of the Caro Kann with Panov/Botvinnik Attack before our match or have I stumped you?

RATING: 6
I like it, even though I'm not very good.  I get the idea if I played a lot I'd improve, but playing once every couple of years just isn't doing it for me.  The game doesn't have enough random elements to ensure novices have a chance to beat experts.  I know for a lot of folks thats a selling point, but for me, it is only a selling point if the game has enough variety that I want to play it 10,000 times.  Chess has very little variety as the board and pieces are static.  A lot of its popularity is basically self-perpetuating.  Its popular because its popular.  I like the game and I'd play it a lot more if I had a willing opponent with a similar skill level.  However, I don't like knowing I am going to win or knowing I am going to lose before every game, and that is what chess brings if your opponent is much better than you.

RATING: 8
Wonderful abstract game. Can be learned at a young age and has much strategic depth. Although I despise the fact that to be competitive means memorizing openings, learning them actually can make you a better player. Room for creativity, with lots of different tactics (development, sacrifice, point values, pins, forks, etc.). Unfortunately, it isn't much fun unless you are at a reasonably similar skill level. (not likely)

RATING: 8
more you play and the better you get the more enjoyable it becomes.  I used to think it was all about calculating lots of moves ahead and then I discovered although you have to think things through you can play well just by commanding space, setting your pawns in good formations, not wasting time/moves on silly things and building pressure on the board with your strong pieces which then allows you to use tactics such as pins and fork attacks.  You then pressure your opponent into destruction.

RATING: 9
Chess has got to be one of the best games around. I just can't give it a full 10 though simply because I feel Go is a better game. It's always easier to find opponents for chess though. Every time I play, chess forces me to think and rethink about the position on the board, the possible moves that can be played, the consequence of every decision you  make having sometimes very different results than what you were expecting. Chess has also taught me patience, perseverance and humility: you just have to recognize defeat when it happens. Its a battle of minds and it can be pretty violent at times. Kasparov once said that chess is the most violent sport there is. I own several chess sets.

RATING: 8
An absolutely timeless classic. I learned to play this in third grade (as a part of the provincial math curriculum at the time) and its been a big part of my life since (e.g., chess competitions in elementary and middle school, frequent matches in undergrad, online chess on and off). 

While the game doesn't come to account for differing levels of skill very well, when it does the matches are incredibly deep -- it's always interesting how different people approach the game. I'm also fine with losing a game to someone far more experienced than I am -- especially if I learn a thing or two from my defeat.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The classic perfect information game.  I have unfortunately been subject to carnivorous chess players in my young age, which has driven me away from chess.  I will only play it if it is friendly, and my opponent is at a similar skill level as myself.  

The game itself isn't bad, what I object to is the culture of "I'm better than you" that is wrapped around the game.  It is all about intellectual superiority.  I prefer games to involve some cooperation and a small to medium amount of luck.  I would like games to be accessible to various levels and various strategies, and to sometimes reward weaker players.  I also want game sessions that allow some socialization.  

If a person leans towards chess instead of family board games, I will suggest traditional card games first (such as Cribbage or Spades).
