=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It takes one day learn, but a lifetime to master.

A timeless classic, and maybe the ultimate board game.
Probably the most-known game overall, which, opposed to traditional card games, has this one set of rules no matter where you play.
(Of course there are still countless alternations like fairy chess - which is a lot of fun too, but traditional chess is THE game.)

Also it's probably the most scientifically studied one, both regarding strategies to solve chess problems as well as regarding positive effects on those actively playing chess.

I'm myself neither an active chess player nor particularly good at it. Nonetheless, i love it.

First-move advantage aside, this is also one of the fairest board games i know.

I guess the average score is just slightly above 7 because not everyone (me included :D) gets as much fun out of playing it as he or she gets from a more light-hearted, colorful and/or action-filled game.

But i consider this game pretty much perfect, therefore this gets a full 10/10 from me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Ideal Players: 2

Description: The classic game of deterministic strategy.

Pro: Elegant rules, finely crafted pieces, and a long tradition of sophistication. 

Con: Very simple basic rules and no theme. Because the game is simple and deterministic, differing levels of experience and skill can make the game lopsided.

RATING: 10
The great grandparent of abstract, skill-focused games. It probably doesn’t deserve its reputation as the mascot for snooty, academic intellectualism, but it demands thought and attention to detail like very little else. It can be a bit daunting to catch onto.

I’m surprised it doesn’t do *all that* well among board gamers generally — maybe the lack of a theme? But I don’t play games for the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm one of those hipsters that thinks Chess is still pretty cool.

Is it perfect? No. But it IS still a great "perfect information" abstract strategy game that rewards creative thinking, malleable tactics, and strategic planning all equally. It is very rewarding to learn the game and get better, and a joy to play face to face with another equally skilled opponent. Don't play chess against computers except for learning and to kill time, or it will suck the soul out of the game. 

It's not for everyone, obviously. It can hurt your brain to use it so much, I understand. And I definitely dislike the culture of "openings" (which is why I love variants like Chess960), but despite any minor flaws the game might have, I would always recommend anyone to give it a try. 

I feel it's a little too "cool" to bash on older games these days, especially Chess. I personally think it's a great game, and worthy of it's classic status.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I promise chess is not as hard to learn as you think; I learned how to play chess in about five minutes.  I love the way it challenges my mind and how you have to learn to anticipate your opponent's next moves.

RATING: 10
The best game ever created. Simplicity in movement combined with complexity in strategy and enormous variation are distilled into an elegance no other game so far devised can match. Best to play someone who is similar in skill or it doesn't work. There's a reason this is one of the most widely owned games and it was created over 500 years ago! Get a nice board ... its worth it. Can also be displayed as a piece of art. Some people hate this game because they haven't put in the time to play it competently, but it is worth the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Chess and all it's small variants is still game with endless play-ability. I like the fact that the more you play it, the better you can get at it. If you invest time into learning this game you can certainly derive years of enjoyment from participating in pick-up games and tournaments. The problem is that in order for this game to play evenly, you must have players who are at an even skill, knowledge and familiarity level. That can be tough to find outside of tournaments. So, that's what makes this only an occasional game for me. Also, even with the royal war theme it's still very abstract and mathy. I prefer games with more theme and depth in the content.

RATING: N/A
Mayans vs. Conquistadors 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
To me, this is not a board game; it's a mental sport.  I know that sounds pretentious, but Chess was my first gaming love and a competitive passion throughout my school years. I haven't played much lately (except for the occasional speed chess game online), because I really don't want the intense competition anymore. This makes it difficult for me to rate it objectively.  Chess is justifiably classified as an abstract strategy game; however, the abstractions are directly relevant to concepts of warfare with things like flanks, weak points, inititiative, area control, and superior force (both overall and at the point of attack) all being relevant.  You really can't appreciate these things, though, unless you spend a significant amount of time with the game.  Chess is a jealous mistress like so many of the "lifestyle" games (MtG, D&D, etc.) that are typically shunned here on BGG. But unlike most of these games chess does not need endless variations to keep its hold--all it needs are simple, yet incredibly elegant rules that have been playtested for 400 years or so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I like chess.  Every once in awhile I'll play a few games against an AI and I like playing face-to-face... 

On the other hand, the game can be very unforgiving.  When playing people/AI much more skilled, you need to be prepared to get beaten resoundly for the smallest errors.  Each game seems as though both players are on a see-saw: the farther a game starts tipping in one player's favor, the harder it is for the game to tip back... exponentially so. This can make trying to learn how to play better through gameplay extremely frustrating as it's nnot always clear what was done wrong to begin the downfall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Why do some people think this game is so hard? I know a lot of people who don't know how to play and aren't willing to learn because they think it's too tough. Learning the rules is one thing though, understanding the strategies and complexities is another.  Therein lies my beef, not with the game but with...I dunno, society? Want to get very good very quickly?  Go read a chess strategy book. You'll probably be instantly better than someone who has actually played the game a number of times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

Chess is Beauty. Chess is Art. Chess is a way of life.

There are more books written about Chess than all games combined multiplied by 50. Only the Bible has more written on it then Chess.

More games of chess are played daily then any other games in the world. No other game has household World Champion recognizable names. Fischer, Kasporov, Lasker, Tal etc..

Movies feature chess set prominitely. The Smithsonian has President John Adams chess set on display. Advertisement uses Chess pieces to represent well calculated moves. 

Chess summons up images of suave, sophisticated and brainy.
Everyone dreams to be the World Champion.

Thousands of opening moves. Admittedly only a few hundred are really ever used. What house does not have a chess set sitting around it that is not collecting dust on the pieces or the box that the pieces are sitting in?

------original review------------
Grand Daddy of them all. For those that play it is art. For those that dabble its no fun. Play you anytime, anywhere. I'll may not win, but you will have no cakewalk.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
"When I speak of the beauty of a game of chess, then naturally this is subjective. Beauty can be found in a very technical, mathematical game for example. That is the beauty of clarity. It is not fireworks and also not a huge achievement of fantasy. Beauty can equally be found in precision. And then there are games, which are perhaps technically imperfect, but the power of imagination in them is full of beauty. I believe every chess player senses beauty, when he succeeds in creating situations, which contradict the expectations and the rules, and he succeeds in mastering this situation. Therein resides the beauty of a spontaneous game strategy, an idea which may be irrational and requires no logic, but is full of power and can be successfully realized." -Kramnik

RATING: 7

I greatly enjoy playing with other people who have not studied the game... I love learning more about it and someday may learn the different variances however I just do not feel that the time investment is worth having a game where it's really dependent on your opponent being of equal skill to provide a sufficient challenge or a good game for that matter.

RATING: 8
Simply an excellent game with huge depth. A classic with a large player base over the whole world. 

Whats keeps me from rating it higher is the immense amount of theoretical study which is required to improve beyond a certain point. You also need to have two reasonably level players to have fun.  

I used to play competitive chess during the late 70:s and have played at least 2000 games, but nowadays only plays occasionally. My most memorable game was on a long train trip in India. After a while we had all passengers as spectators.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Now, I realize that not everyone enjoys such a pure thinking game, but this can't keep me from calling it a perfect game.  100 years from now, people will still be writing books about chess strategy, and people will still be studying games played two hundred years before them.  Every time I play chess, I keep thinking, "What a perfect game this is!"  Of course, I don't mean perfect for every situation--you wouldn't pull out a chessboard when you've got a bunch of friends over for your birthday, after all--but the game itself just can't be improved upon.

RATING: 10
Ebony/Stauton style & Tourney set.  I really feel this game should be taught in our school system, K-12th.  It teaches a child to think ahead and consider the consequences of their current position in relation to others... a substantial lesson on life in a kinda-sorta Zen way. 

You can bet that my sons know how to play.

RATING: 9
Since I play and practice chess a lot, I probably find it less fun than many good euro games.  Also, the requirement to memorize openings in order to consistently emerge from the opening with an acceptable position is extremely annoying.  However, playing a long time control chess game is extremely rewarding.  The game isn't exactly elegant, but the fact that is complex, and that there are millions of people who play it at all levels, and many, many opportunities to play it face-to-face makes it worth it to study the game, and the more you put in it, the more you get out of it.  I'm sure Go is the same way, but I haven't yet reached the same level of play in Go that I have in chess.  I just wish that everyone would switch to Fischer-Random Chess!

RATING: 6.25
I haven't played chess for many years and I would only tackle it again if really in the mood.  For two players only.

Predecessor game originated in Gupta India before the 7th Century A.D.  Moved west via Persia and Islamic conquests into Spain, from where it spread into Europe.  Rules standardized when international tournaments became popular after the Staunton design came out in 1849.

RATING: 10

It is not something for a gaming night, but I couldn't possibly rate it anything less than 10.

RATING: 4
I have a really beautiful set in a handsome box. The board lets it down a bit, but it's still pretty impressive.

Chess is a bit of a Marmite game. I'm reasonably good at it, but I don't like it much, since I was inoculated against it by my father who insisted that I play him night after night after night, and who thrashed me every time we played. He used to play for Cambridge when he was an undergraduate, and was probably close to master level, but he was a terrible teacher. There's no fun in starting a game knowing from before either of you move a pawn that he's going to wipe the floor with you.

I recognise that the game of chess is brilliant, with a huge depth and strategic interest. My ranking is strictly in line with the BGG guidelines, and means "I could be talked into it on occasion". 

But I still like my chess set.

RATING: 7
I understand why this has been the standard for a battle of wits for centuries but it's hard to rank on here.  

In terms of game mechanics even a 10 seems to fall short of measuring the beautiful, elegant simplicity.

However, this is a game where the best player virtually always wins.  Great for showing Chess as an intellectual  measuring stick, not a great thing for people to say about a board game.  

An early disadvantage can be almost impossible to overcome, also not usually considered a plus in the board game world.

I'm just putting a 7 on this one and moving on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Favorite Variant: Bug House
(a.k.a: Doubles, Doubles Speed, Bunk House, Siamese Chess) 

Two teams of two, each playing their own opponent on a separate board but an opposite color from your partner. When capturing pieces, give them to your partner so that your partner may place that captured piece as their move (Pawns cannot be placed on the first or last rank). If a pawn is promoted, place it on its side and remember it's new role. When one player loses, the team loses. Must be played with chess clocks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of those games that you can literally spend your whole life playing and never exhaust the depth.  I played scholastic and tournament chess for many years, and later online correspondence.  I play much less now that I have gotten into modern boardgames, but I am still always down for a game.  Probably not so fun for casual players, but if you can stick with it long enough to get to an intermediate level, there is just so much to explore.  Consider that you can talk about aesthetics and "beauty" regarding a game of chess... and not be talking about the components! lol.

RATING: 10
Absolutely and without a doubt, this game is on a very very small list of the most incredibly awesome games every invented. I hope that was clear and unambiguous.

But... it really is a different category of "game" altogether from the rest of the games I've rated. It's more like a "mental workout" than something you'd conventionally think of as "fun".

It's also extremely unforgiving, and it only takes a small difference in player skill to make it virtually unwinnable by the weaker player. Meaning that it's hard to find a good match.

Still -- I wish I played this game more.  In the meantime, a great way to scratch the itch is http://chess.emrald.net!

RATING: 9
Now this game is the she ite. No Luck, Pure Strategy. What could be wrong with this game. Well, you have to factor in the fact that any one person's chess skill can be anywhere from 0 to 1,000,000. What I'm saying is that some people live, eat, and drink this game. So even though you may beat the crap out of your friends everytime you play them (me) you get your ass handed to you when you play someone who actually knows what they are doing (me playing someone at the local coffee house). Considering the fact that I like a variety when I game, I can't see myself devoting my life to just one game so that in 10 years or so I can actually stand a chance with the experts. Still, this is a great game that deserves a 9/10.

RATING: 8
Chess is the undisputed champion among western abstract strategy games.  Yet, after four centuries of play and analysis, I think some of the fun has gone out of it.  However, I imagine that few, if any, of our sophisticated modern games will stand the test of time like chess has.  I am personally burned out on chess, but variations like Knightmare and Fischer random can keep it interesting.  Everyone should learn how to play chess.  Even if it’s not to your taste consider it a history lesson.

RATING: 6
If I valued pure design over how much I enjoy playing them, I would have given Chess a 10. This game has kept alive for all this time and acquired so much prestige for a reason.

So, what prevents me from giving this a 10? Chess now is more a sport than a game, which gets us to what, for me, kills the fun from it: it has been overstudied. That creates a lot of imbalance in between players with different skill levels, as well as reducing creative play a lot. I enjoy playing with people of my level, but that's a rare occurrence.

Fun fact: I do enjoy Go quite a lot, despite having the same drawback as Chess. Maybe because it isn't so widespread, as I have an easier time finding players of my level. Who knows...

RATING: 6
[size=12][b]Top 100-200 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Chess:[/b][/size]
+ Just about everybody knows the rules so there is rarely a time where you need to teach the game.
+ I like the mechanics of the game
+ There is high player involvement.
+ The game requires meaningful decisions to win.
+ The game seems to have high replayability

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Chess:[/b][/size]
/ Playing with somebody who is more experienced than you is less fun. You ought to play at a similar level.

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Keep & Sometimes willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Chess has evolved during 100s of years into its current form. The theme has some nice medieval touch to it, kings sit next to their queens, the queens are much more powerful than their spouse, normal pawns can promote in their life if they survive and progress.

Chess is language independent, it is part of international culture, like soccer: if you are in a pub in, say, Bali, you can quickly break the ice with the locals by inviting them to play a game of chess. That alone is a reason to at least know how to play it, and it requires no wifi. 

The interesting thing is that no piece is safe, only the position of a piece is safe if it is reached by more of your other pieces than of the opponent's pieces. With players of about equal strenght it is a very tight game.

However:
-1 too contrived rules: en passent, promotion
-1  no obligation to slay a piece.
-1 too often the end result is a draw for a game of no chance which feels like a bummer if you were obviously better but could't win.
-1 a better player always wins and there is no handicap option
-1 to progress beyond some basic level you need to learn a whole bunch of opening theory
-1 can take hours and nothing to do, too much downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
While I beat pretty much anyone I ever play chess with, I know I'm really not that good at it. That is, if I played this in a park or on a campus with some stranger, I'd probably get my butt handed to me. While I love chess, I just don't think it's that good of a game due to skill being so important. I love that the skill can really show you who is truly better at it, but at the same time it's just not that fun when you know that it's probably not going to be much of a contest, that either you or them probably has no shot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Chess is a two-player, abstract strategy board game that represents medieval warfare on an 8x8 board with alternating light and dark squares. Opposing pieces, traditionally designated White and Black, are initially lined up on either side. Each type of piece has a unique form of movement and capturing occurs when a piece, via its movement, occupies the square of an opposing piece. Players take turns moving one of their pieces in an attempt to capture, attack, defend, or develop their positions. Chess games can end in checkmate, resignation, or one of several types of draws. Chess is one of the most popular games in the world, played by millions of people worldwide at home, in clubs, online, by correspondence, and in tournaments. Between two highly skilled players, chess can be a beautiful thing to watch, and a game can provide great entertainment even for novices. There is also a large literature of books and periodicals about chess, typicially featuring games and commentary by chess masters.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I would recommend that people who like Chess play The Duke.  It has a lot of a similar feel and strategy, but with a lot more variety, not only in not having the same openings every game, but especially in all the different pieces, and you never know which ones you'll get in any given game.  

And the whole thing of each piece having two moving patterns that you alternate through is just so neat.

And the tension of when to bring in new pieces and when to move.

AND the neat powers that some units have, like fear or dread.

AND!! the different ways to play with the mountain or the dragon or the flag.  So it basically just takes some of the core concepts of chess and adds so much more.

So it's not that chess is a really bad game, but I think its experience is only good in a couple areas and other games have added so much to what you can experience in a 2-player abstract strategy game with move-and-capture mechanics.

RATING: 9
There is no other boardgame which has had such an impact on culture (or on other boardgames) as chess. If it was designed today it would probably look very different and would be a small niche game but thankfully it wasn't and just a quick trip to the British Museum (if you are in London) to see the Lewis Chessmen shows the games importance.

Games between players of equal skill are great and games at the highest level are things of beauty.  well worth reading the annotations of the greatest games to see how the best of the best can take a simple game to the highest places.

RATING: 9
I've been playing this game for over 20 years, and still play it a LOT online.  Mostly Turn-based chess on GameKnot, but I also log onto FICS once in a while for real-time play.  Luckily I'm good enough not to be able to play reasonably sensible games most of the time (my rating fluctuates between 1450 and 1525 on both servers).  Unfortunately I don't get to play it FtF very much any more.

EDIT: hard as it is for me to believe, chess has essentially been supplanted by YINSH and GIPF. My online play has tapered off to nothing, and I still haven't played face-to-face lately. Technically, i think I would now have to rate this a 7, but my long, and engaging history with the game makes that feel wrong, so I'll just drop it to a 9 for now.  I may start up some new games on GameKnot soon, too.

RATING: 10
Chess is probably the first game I can remember playing or wanting to play. I used to enjoy playing this game, but it ceased to be fun when I realized how much you must study this game in order to be any good. It feels more like exercise than a gaming experience.

That being said, it is probably the best game I've ever played. It is very pure. No luck, no fiddly mechanics or scoring, just your army verse an equal army. No game has been studied more or had more written about it. It is perfect and has been for centuries. Trying to improve this game is an exercise in futilty.

RATING: 6
Outrage!  How could I possibly give a "6" to a super classic, a game that has withstood the test of time and inspired million of players around the world?  Well, this is a subjective rating base on the BGG scale, how likely I am to play this game again.  The rating for the game itself should probably be a 8 or 9 based merely on uniqueness, mechanics, challenge, and widespread adoption.  However, this is a game where knowledge, practice, the ability to plan in advance and to compute possible outcomes is so important that a beginner does not stand a chance against a master.  I am not interested in mastering such a game, therefore I will use the BGG score and correctly point out that it's a personal 6.

RATING: 3

06/06 - Damn, my 5 year old nephew is really really into chess now. This means I get sucked into games. It's more fun playing with him because we're doing something together, and we're about the same level ;-). Well, just about. He beats me every time.

RATING: 10
Dude, it's chess. Currently I'm about 1500 or 1600 now but I'm preferring Knightmare/Rogue/Moab Chess (with portals/wrap-arounds/fairy pieces) than orthodox chess. I'm pretty much done with folks that have memorized openings. I did that for a while, memorizing a dozen or so openings with variations...no more. Yeah, it's traditional and all that but it's boring and favors memory over tactics and strategy. I don't read the same kind of books endlessly why would I play the same kind of chess. Check out the Chess Variants page on Wikipedia for cool alternatives.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was press-ganged into coaching a school chess club. In that context, I've loved this game. Kids haven't memorized much, their play is full of exploration and discovery, and their games don't take too long.

Outside of chess club, I used to play a few moves a day or short variants. Single-session face-to-face games aren't that fun for me anymore. The mix of chess culture and my obsessive nature turned that from play into work.

Introduce someone who finds Chess too serious or long to a small board, no-setup variant, like [gameid=66283] or Knizia's [gameid=40375]. For a social game, try [gameid=14188]. I enjoy a quick fix of [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minichess]Minichess[/url] variants.

RATING: 9
[i]Number of physical plays since Aug 2013.[/i]

There are few – maybe no other – games that could meet this tense feeling of a battle between two minds. I love it.
 
Unfortunately I think the game is somewhat destroyed by all the books. If you play on a club, you're not really playing your opponent – you're playing the brilliant people who came up with those openings, computer calculations, etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've probably been playing chess longer than any other game I own. It has brought me hours of pleasure. On the other hand, I rarely find myself wanting to play, for a couple of reasons.

First, it is not really all that fun. It is very challenging and mentally stimulating, but I've come to look for fun in my games of late. Chess doesn't really pass muster in this arena.

Second, it is very hard to find someone to play with that has roughly the same skill level. My playing companions are either better or worse than I. Neither situation works out that well. Chess is a game that is best enjoyed with someone with roughly the same skill level.

RATING: 4
======== Skill Floor Level: 4 out of 9
======== Approachability Grade: D

This "Time Chess" variant of my own design introduces a hidden movement aspect. During one third of your moves, you won't know what move the other opponent just made, because their pieces become hidden for that move. (This variant can also be done with some other 2-player games.)

RATING: 8.3
I grew playing chess and I absolutely love it.

It is hard to bring it to the table, as most people think it is too hard to learn and feel overwhelmed before even touching a chessman.

And it is, in a way, hard to learn, but mostly because people don't really want to learn it.

Also, when the players' skills are not about even, the fun gets compromised. When the weaker player is not interested in improving her skills on after-play analysis it gets even more compromised.

It is a pity that most people don't see the its beauty just because they feel scared by its depth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good game for 'casual' all the way to 'very serious' people/settings. Ubiquitous, comes in a vast variety of sizes, materials, styles, and price ranges. Strategically complex, but not overly so.

Still, I find it being overshadowed more and more by abstract games such as Go and Arimaa as I age and play more games. However, I've found ways to extend the longevity of chess, by using the components as (or supplementing them with) esoteric game design tools. 
For starters, chess variants are easy to invent. The 6 unit types can be drawn on blank dice to randomly decide the army each player gets. 
A game I've seen but don't have, Chesstique, does something similar to this, except I think it only has certain units on each die and lets you choose the unit.
The implications of these simple mechanical changes are only the tip of the iceberg.

As for vanilla chess: It's something I'll play with a friend. I guess it's a game I only want when either experimenting or when in the company of someone I'd play anything with. Playing chess in a casual or 'speed' fashion definitely feels less taxing than trying to do the same with Go or Arimaa. There are very few questions in chess to resolve, mostly just castling. 

I suppose chess feels just like what it is: a strategic skirmish game with a hint of territory control to it. I like depth to my units and to their interactivity, and this means more than just changing the shape of the patterns in which they can move. Still, chess fills a niche nothing else can ever quite dislodge it from.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Rating based on 2 players.

This is a good example of my ratings being a reflection more about how much I want to play a game than the quality of the game, perse; I recognize the elegance, the in-depth strategy, the aesthetic purity of chess... and yet I don't like playing it at all. Chess is one of the very few turn-based games that really stresses me out to play. I think much of that is that it boils down to a perfect-information game that is purely attritional where it's possible to lose in two moves--I feel like I'm in constant "sudden death" mode. And yes, I'm horrible at it too!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was pretty obsessed with Chess from ages 8-16 or so, was a decent club player (~1500 elo), did some minor tournaments, etc.

Chess is great in terms of tactical problems and thinking. But as I played more and more, the following things started to bother me:
1) At some point, you really need to memorize openings. Otherwise, despite reading ability, you will get trounced. I found this part tedious.
2) Draws are frequent, and wins are often small (e.g. managing to gain one pawn advantage, and protecting it until the endgame).
3) No handicap system, so to play interesting games you need to find players close to your skill level. This is easy enough online, but considerably harder if you want to play in person.
4) This is minor, but from an aesthetic point of view some of the rules seem odd/arbitrary (e.g. pawn en passant is capturing a piece and not moving where it was located; castling has 2 pieces moving simultaneously, and the possibility depends on both their movement history and whether intermediate squares are attacked).

So not a game I play much nowadays, but definitely a game I think people should learn/play for a while.

I don't know Chinese and Japanese chess well enough to compare (only played them a couple times).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Lovely abstract that somehow looks magnificent even when played with cheap plastic pieces. Has an almost unbeatable cerebral (as opposed to geek) reputation. Can feel rather scripted at times, especially at the start and finish, and opponents need to be well-matched. More fun with a chess clock; kills the downtime, boosts the tension and gameplay rarely suffers all that much.

RATING: 4.444
It is Chess, the most aggressively anti-social game of all time. Players routinely mistake aptitude and experience for intelligence or wit.

It is fun with the right partner; true expertise requires thousands of hours a year and many years of training, including considerable rote memorization of openings and positions.

It is not actually balanced (white has a notable statistical advantage), and it is far too prone to draws.

The expansions are also a letdown.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The truth is that I love chess, and always have, but there are two camps that almost every chess player will fall into: The noob who has no idea about strategy and the pro who has memorized openings and takes the game altogether too seriously. I myself fall sort of into the latter camp, but then I reflect on it and realize that that's not what a game is supposed to be like. I'll gladly play it any time, but I think other 2-player abstracts need to get more love.

Though it's quite probable no one will ever read this, I need to add that various aspects of chess (particularly in the endgame, but sometimes throughout) encourage the most despicable aspects of human nature (sneaking around, squirming, pathetically hiding and hoping that the other guy will make the first mistake so you can pounce...). Even if I win against such a person, I despise the game for days thereafter and don't even want to look at it. It disgusts me that people play like that, but the game honestly rewards it most of the time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Good capture game that sets the standard

RATING: 7.5
---
Elegant gameplay, a classic.
My nr1 most played game in childhood. 
Every kid & adult should try this game!
Highly suited for competitive play.
Brain burner.
I got bored with this game.
:
Strategy: very high
Luck: low (opponent mistakes/skill)
Target: kids, family, competitive gamers.
Components: high (because of so many choices)
Rules: easy
Replay value: high
Downtime & Analysis paralysis: medium-high (solve this with a clock specially designed for this game).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Generic game, like Tactics II or Blitzkrieg, but with less terrain differentiation. Much more unit-type differentiation than most wargames, with unique movement and combat systems. There is no stacking, even during movement (with an exception wrt Knights). The CRT is very unusual, strongly favors the attacker, and strongly favors counterattack-based defenses. There is only one result, DE, and it occurs regardless of the odds ratio or the die roll. It can have very subtle strategies, but it has none of the history I look for in a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I learned the game when I was 10 and played it during high school lunch hours in Grades 10 and 11. I own a very nice chess set: not a wooden board or anything like that, but a "Chess Tube", which has the same high-quality plastic pieces I used in high school along with a roll-up board. 

I lucked out and defeated the president of the Victoria Chess Club when I was about 21 or 22 years old, but I'm not sure if I ever played the game after that time. I got really interested in the game but gave up. Would never go back--simply too much memorization and being quiet. Never tried speed chess.

RATING: 7
Each week, on friday afternoon, I play chess with my 6th grade students.  I did and still do this for the last 10 years.  In this lapse of time, I came to realise that chess is more than a game, it's an history book waiting to be explained.  I still find opponent more than worthy enough, even though they are young.  I've been handed my ass over more than once in this time.  I am so proud when it happens.

Being responsible for the yearly chess tournament in my school, I love to see students progressing.  Chess is all about logic.  I hearthily suggest it to parents with their kids.

RATING: 10
The best strategic and tactical game in existence for centuries.  As gamers we owe it a great debt.  It was the first really serious game I ever played and I went on to become a rated tournament chess player.  Sadly its days became numbered a computer finally beat the world champion, but it's still a great game.  One of the few abstract games that I like.  It's a very, very deep game that at its best creates a link between the two player's minds unlike anything I've ever experienced.

RATING: 10
The most exciting board game ever invented. Comments like 'the game will be solved by computers in x years' are really silly, since the game is really a battle of the minds; it's a fight between two players, not a bunch of scripted moves. The aspect of the game which really sets it apart for me is that the great games played throughout history are immortal works of art to those who understand the game. I've probably played many thousands of games, and whenever I play an equal or better opponent I never fail to get surprised, even when I seem to have everything well in hand. A beautiful and mysterious game.

RATING: 5
I rather like Chess. Im not a complete beginner but not remotely any good (I recon I could maybe hope to hold a 1200-1300 rating at this point in time but I might be deluding myself), and since I'm not about to join a club I just have online or AI as the only places for me to find opponents at the same level. I could choose differently of course, but I don't feel that much of a draw to play more.

My interest in Chess has also been superseded by Go, which I feel offers a more "organic" quality to the game and the exploration of the underlying framework - it's a game I more often get the "Oh, so that's how it is!" discoveries during play. The ability to handicap myself or my opponent means that it's easier to play anyone - regardless of experience! So ye, that leaves Chess to the point where I play the occasional game online or against an AI - or just do tactical puzzles.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Game in a Nutshell: Attempt to capture the opponent's king by using the individual qualities of different pieces.  

Two-player only.

Pros: Apparently it can't be solved if humans can beat computers at it, so it's definitely not broken.

Cons: It's not a game, it's a lifestyle. And that's how it feels: In the chess world, if you're a loser you're less of a person. If you don't want to buck-up and learn the game, it's like the regulars think you're running from life, rather then just deciding you don't like to play. It's the culture around chess that really brings this game down... not that it's all that fun in the first place.

Other: I can think of plenty of other abstract games that feel easier to pick up on and enjoy even while still getting my butt kicked by someone more experienced. Most namely: Changgi.

Best Use: Gives the 'intellectual' crowd something to make them feel good about themselves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My #30.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After a few hundred plays. Classic and very fun to play, but takes a points hit for having what today would be considered serious design flaws.  Very high draw rates among skilled players, kludgy rules to prevent infinite cycles, too easy to tabulate opening libraries, etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
How can this not be rated higher?  This game has been played more than just about any other. It's one of a handful of games that has it's own literature, which can be quite satisfying.  It admits a wide variety of playing styles and situations.  Surprising and beautiful moves are quite common -- how often are you truly surprised by a player's move in a Eurogame?

A lot of people resent all the chess theory, but that is only an issue if you want to play in tournaments.  You can still have fun without a rating.

RATING: 4
A pretty good game that I simply have limited patience for. Admirable for its elegance and replayability, it also is supremely frustrating. Although in some ways it does model elements of pre-gunpower combat, it is too abstract for my tastes. I agonize over every move, so much so that other people have thrown up their arms and quit. I can't understand the people who devote their lives to this game. It's just a game. I downgraded to a 5 because I simply cannot imagine wanting to play this, except solo against the computer to kill a little time. This has the added advantage that I can accuse my "opponent" of cheating and quit midway without guilt. You know, just for fun.

RATING: 6
01/08/2013: I have a weird fascination with chess.  I really find the game compelling.  I love its elegance.  If I were a wealthy person, I'd have hundreds of chess sets in my home as I find them so intriguing to display and admire.  I even own some books on chess and chess strategy.

But do I actually play the game?  Almost never.  I've taught it to my girls, but they do not have the patience or time to put into learning its intricacies.  Heck, I don't either.  And yet, I'm still pulled toward this classic game.

Maybe some day...

RATING: 10
The game of kings and the best boardgame ever made. There is no luck or coincidence, just pure skill and good/bad decisions, for this reason its also one of the only truly competitive games. It's one of the deepest games in existence, you could spend a life trying to master chess and by then you would still have things to learn. The replayability is off the chart with almost infinitely different positions.

The only bad thing I can say about this game is that because chess is a skill game it requires the players to be somewhere equal in strenght.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I remember winning the 3rd Grade Chess Championship.  My prize? Mickey Mouse glow-in-the-dark calendar, how cool was that?  Also remember in 5th grade going to a chess club and our teacher was from India.  Each week one of us got to play him.  I beat him and he kept asking how I did it and what book I read.  I've never read a chess book nor do I ever intend to.  Chess is just a fun game for me. Then I came in the top 10 in elementary school in 5th grade. The championship was organized by the librabrian a big chess nut.  She had a live size board with students dressed up to move as the two battled it out.  Oh yes, I really suck at playing since it's been awhile since I've played.  Come on elementary students...game on.  I'll play a game of chess with ya!

RATING: 7
An obvious classic that I love.  I think the game itself is a little lacking, since the piece movement is not particularly simple.  The complexity is what makes it great, but the strict opening is a deterrent for me.  To get better at Chess you have to study Chess and the knowledge will only help you at Chess.  Chess960 sounds like an interesting solution to the opening book problem, but I have not tried it yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played fanatically between the ages of about 8 and 18, and got up to county standard.  I found that at the level where I was getting a decent game, I usually ended with about 15 minutes on my clock and around 90 minutes on my opponent's clock = around 75 minutes of boredom.  At that point, I switched to bridge and RPGs, until I eventuallly discovered European games.

I still play casually*, usually at 5 minutes a game, but the best use of a chess set is to play Alice Chess or Progressive Chess; or with two chess sets, Bughouse.  

*Colliers Wood chess club, Donald Hope Library, Saturdays, 2pm (ish)-5pm.
I also play via Chesspresso (turn-based android app) - challenge mrraow.

Chess is probably what got me hooked on abstracts in the first place and the way of thinking that I learned playing chess has made it easier for me to pick up strategies in just about every other game I've played since, but if I saw it for the first time now, I'd be sadly disappointed.  If you're thinking of taking up a traditional board game, go wipes the floor with chess.  Using Chinese scoring at least, go feels like it was designed; nice simple logical rules which make the rules of chess look very clumsy by comparison.

Oh, yes, I've invented a few chess variants.  Some are in David Pritchard's encyclopedia of chess variants, a couple of others are here: http://www.scat.demon.co.uk/free.html#chess - Quantum Chess is the only one that bears repeated play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'd avoided this game since getting into "modern" board games a few years ago. Chess just seemed old-fashioned and boring given all the new stuff I was experiencing. The few face-to-face games I played since getting into the BGG craze only confirmed this impression.

However, I recently started playing this again on the iPad and on my phone, and I'm completely hooked. This used to be my go-to game, and I've been sucked in again. I realize that many of the new games I like most share similarities with Chess. There remain some things I don't like, which could result in another dry spell someday, but there's so much "depth" here that I know I'll still be playing this decades from now.

Update: Yup, another dry spell for sure. It's just not "exciting" enough to get into unless I'm already into it. I force myself to play for the 10x10 Challenge and always enjoy it, but it takes a few plays to get back in the groove. I'm docking the rating a point for now, but I can see it going back up if I start playing it all the time on my phone or something.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Do modern board games have the same amount of possible moves & strategies? Could they possible be able symbolize the whole of life like Chess does? I find it hard to imagine, but who knows. The former, maybe, it is "just" an abstract, after all. The latter, no. Maybe Go? Oh wait, that's not modern... 

Of course, to grossly simplify, culturally Go is for Asian cultures what Chess is to the Occident. Anyway, I still find it funny how people say there are dozens of better abstracts than Chess or Go, as this simply is not the case. Yes, these bad boys have got some insane history and cultural sediments under their belts, so I guess the comparison is quite unfair. But such is life.

Do I play Chess? Not really, no. But I do like to read about it occasionally. Does it rock hard? Oh my summer children, it surely does.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
My love for this game is not describable, nor reasonable, nor healthy or free from frustration. It is a mix of a multitude of things.

The old heritage, the worldwide spread, the timeless quality, the abstract factor, the creativity. Those are only a few of the aspects that make chess a great game. For most people it is a game that will forever have secrets, something that can accompany them for a lifetime. 

It can be played for fun, competitively, it can be studied, it can make you both sad and happy. Let's not forget, however, that it is still just a game. But what a great one.

RATING: 7
I played avidly in elementary and middle school, and though I was no longer the top of the heap in high school I still played quite a bit there as well.  However, I got somewhat discouraged in college (it seemed like I would've been near the bottom of the chess club ladder there) and between that and other interests I haven't played much recently (though I do follow chess news to some extent).

Still, very engaging game when one's opponent is of roughly the same skill, and a recent enjoyable game reminded me why I like it.  I don't know that I'll be suggesting it much more in the future (there are still numerous other two-player games I'd like to play more), but if challenged I probably won't decline.

The game just has no draw for me although it is obviously one of the deepest and most thoughtful games around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A holy cow often backed by arguments in the vein of "it's been a worldwide activity since before my birth and still exists". Coming from a community who poops on Monopoly at every occasion, we should know better than defending the mainstream consensus. Many of us probably picked up Chess as kids, like religion or football, and ourselves taking a critical look at it may be part of an identity crisis we'd rather not have.

The main problem with Chess is once you've tackled its basics and are able to set up forks and stuff, memorising hundreds of openings will be more efficient than any other path of progression. High level play, where creativity seems to take place again, isn't better since it results in 60% draws, which no modern competitive game would be proud of.

The good news is that if you own a chess set, you can now play Arimaa. Seriously, give it a try.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Tout a été dit sur le roi des jeux! Un grand classique et un classique qui le restera. Je connais peu de gens qui ne possède pas un jeu d'échecs à la maison. Personnellement, ce fût le premier jeu auquel je me suis adonné (à l'âge de 4 ans) et je sais que ce jeu m'accompagnera sur mon lit de mort!

Deux joueurs. Deux acteurs. Une scène. Et l'histoire se crée un coup à la fois.

Dans tous les pays que j'ai visités, j'ai toujours fini par croiser des gens qui jouaient aux échecs dans un parc, et à chaque fois, j'ai immédiatement éprouvé le sentiment que ces joueurs et moi faisions partie de la même grande famille.

Et chaque fois que je vois un jeu d'échecs, mon regard est immédiatement captivé, et je ne peux qu'admirer l'harmonie initiale de la position, qui cache pourtant un potentiel d'une si grande violence!

Être assis et jouer une partie pendant quatre, cinq, six heures, c'est accepter de souffrir. Mais ne dit-on pas qu'aimer, c'est souffrir!?...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Chess is one of the classic games - to play properly requires 2 1/2 hrs of time on each clock.  When I was 15 years old, I got a rating of 1700 in Canada, played tournaments in Hong Kong beating a couple of 1900 rated players. My great "accomplishment" was drawing the grandmaster Najdorf when he was playing 40 players simultaneously in Hong Kong in 1986, and I was only one of two people to draw him. Unfortunately, I haven't raised a chess piece in anger for many years. I have only played the odd social game with co-workers, but haven't played blitz or anything that sharpens my skill. My skills have declined to the point where I easily blunder away pieces now. Chess will always be one of my favorite games, but I don't think I could find the time to play tournament matches again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fun game that I quite loved as a child. Now that I've discovered designer games, I find that I wish Chess had more theme/variability. I've looked up variants like Different Dimension Chess (where you set up two boards and after a piece moves, it teleports to the other board) and the random start setup Chess, but I still don't like that there can such a huge gap in skill between players. I suppose thats good, but I think this is only really, really fun with someone at your skill level. If its someone too weak or too strong...its not as fun as modern designer games.

Fun fact: Ive played a master before (it was 30 of us against her), and Ive also won a chess tournament before. These are memories from my HS chess club. I also beat my school's first board relatively consistently (I always held second board position but got better that I eventually beat him even when I would lose a rook in the beginning) and beat my chess teacher in a 3 hour long game before graduating, so I'm decently proud of myself for that.

Plays: 30-50+?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The emperor of abstracts. Well, there's no much rest for the weary: This classical brainburner never seizes to pour gazoline onto my brains and willingly provides a match. It feels more like work (in a see-through cube set up by Mensa, on a sunday) than play. 60 minutes? Lies, lies and statistics... But Chess' importance for, wait for the melodramatic insert...[b]*mankind*[/b], cannot be underestimated. An how many board games have a musical to their name? Not Puerto Rico, that's for sure (all it has to its name is a small role in West Side Story). Or can be played with supersized pieces in parks, against hobos who'll probably beat you? Not Caylus, that's for sure. Additionally, Chess is one of the few games that have a global meaning well beyond the gaming realm. Damn you Bobby Fischer! But hey, lest us not forget what comes with the game: few games can display so many annoying child prodigies (with even more annoying parents en entourage) and eccentric nutcases in tournaments: -1 point, but an extra point for never giving birth to a single expansion during its 2000 years rule. I'm probably wrong, but I don't want to know.

full review at:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/111787

RATING: 10
Chess is simply the king of all games. I mean it's such a simple game yet it's extremely strategic, it's theoretical, and at times it's indubitably beautiful. An easy game to play but a hard one to master; learning tons of opening lines, doing middle game analysis, working on end game techniques. Although I've read my share of chess books and spent hours on game analyses, to be honest I don't play the game that much myself. That being said, I can't think of any other game I would have been willing to watch every single day for the past five years.

Note: I will not be logging any plays of chess, because I find myself constantly indulged in the game and tracking that would be extremely difficult.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The one grand old classic that I play quite regularly. It would take more than one human life to master this game, and I know I play it very badly. I just don't want to use the time it needs. I won't bother learning for example go because I know I won't have the time it deserves either. So chess is the game of which I have some literature and the game about which I want to try to understand at least a little bit.

It's hard to rate chess here. I think I still have to give it a 10 although it responds to a different need for boardgames than other games here. Chess is a perfect game that I play whenever I have time and suitable company for it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This rating is based on hundreds of game plays. I've played chess since childhood and have always enjoyed playing it against opponents of my strength. I am probably only rated around 1500, but that is good because at this level the game is still quite interesting. However, I believe that the game is fundamentally flawed because at high levels of play the game results in too many draws. This is because as the game progresses the ability to attain the goal of the game diminishes for both players. Thus it is not able to differentiate players as well as games like Go. Also if one wants to go beyond casual play it requires a lot of memorization of openings and end games. The domination of Chess by computers is perhaps also hurting the game. I still give Chess a high rating because most people will be casual players and will enjoy the sharp tactics of the game. For anyone interested in a game that can be played with a Chess set, is computer resistant, and still very fresh I would recommend trying out a game that I invented called Arimaa.

RATING: 10
I played a lot of chess growing up, but didn't really get "serious" until firstie year at West Point. That year I played a bumch of quads and octagonals at the Marshall club on weekends and would drive to some others and sleep in my car. After graduating in 1989, I won a class prize for $1,000 in Buffalo, and went on what I called my summer chess tour, going to the National Open in Vegas, and the World Open and Action Chess Championship in Philly. I played a little bit in the Seattle area, but slowly stopped playing tournament chess.

I do play a lot of blitz, and have recently been playing Crazyhouse, which is a Chess/Shogi hybrid.

Nothing beats a few good games of speed chess.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
[2010/01/01] +1,000 plays before recording




I love chess.


Chess is the first TRUE game i ever played. When i was little i played against my mom, i also did some young plp tournements ... in highschool i did the chess team... and after college i did the FICS (free internet chess server) for about a year (the FICS is cool because it calculates your chess rating and lets you play againsts similarly rated plp)

now i don't play so much, but it's only because i don't have a good chess partner... and because there are so many other games to play



Chess is a beautiful game, it's exact, there are correct moves and incorect moves... since I can't comprehend all of chess at once it makes it fun. Chess is a simple excersise between 2 people about whom can comprehend more, and whom can retain their focus for longer.

If you add the timer into chess it becomes different story altogether, now it becomes just as much about time management as anything else... It's still fun, and it's nice to known that the game will at least be over in X minutes, but theres nothing worse than losing for time when you have the tactical advantage

i prefer playing real plp over the computer... it's almost like when playing a real person they have linear thoughts that you can follow based off of thier past moves/games/reactions... each game can get you closer to being able to understand and defeat your opponent. 
Playing the computer is much less fluid, the computer can calculate all moves, but randomly makes bad moves based on a selected "skill level"... playing the computer is almost like solving a brain teaser instead of playing a game. 



i highly recommend this game to kids... it's a great time to get them to start thinking abstractly, develop patience, and to learn how to lose without getting upset.

for adults it can be fun too, but it's extreemly cerebral. I can only really play against other chess players... there is SUCH a learning curb, and if the person isn't patient (i.e. willing to lose about 50 games) their not going to be a fun time... plus i dont think its fun to win 50 straight game against novices either.

I credit this game for helping me to devlop MANY of my tactical and abstract abilities...



an intersting thing about chess is that it is such a black and white "i'm better than you game" that it turns many people off... my favorite opponent is someone that is slightly better than myself, and willing to play many many times... so hopefully i can get better




p.s. I have also played "bughouse" a handfull of times... its a fun varient on chess for 4 plp... it's a great time, but it requires all plp to be on similar levels
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm only an average player, but I've been playing this since I was 7. I once tried to learn it seriously for a year or so, but ultimately, other games are just more enjoyable. I'm usually looking for relaxation in playing, and Chess is another kind of "building site", another type of enjoyment. Chess means brain work and the joy of being able to understand the game. 

It's certainly undisputed that the game itself is outstanding in the sense that it has a special significance. However, I do not believe that this is justified by its design. ANY game of comparable complexity, with identical start and victory conditions and not involving randomness could be studied as deeply as Chess. Openings and end games can be rather formal. It's only fun when both the players perform on the roughly same skill level. 

In other words: I think it is overrated.

RATING: 7
Chess is the first game I remember playing.  My father taught me to play at an early age, out of desperation for someone to play with, I believe.  The set we played on had rooks that were elephants, which I found enchanting.  Although I'm not a particularly strong player, I will never turn down an opportunity to play.  It's a very challenging, exciting and dynamic game that requires concentration and focus.  You need not be a master to get a great deal of satisfaction from a game of chess, but finding an opponent of fairly equal skill level will make the experience much more enjoyable for both players. (4+3)

RATING: 10
Perfection over the centuries! Both players have the exact same resources in the exact same layout! No room for luck, no silly excuses: you play right you win, you play wrong you loose! No secret cards, no hidden advantages, transparent and simple, yet very deep and complex! Best game ever given to mankind. I won't give any other game a perfect score, the best any other game can get compared to this one is 9.9 at most. No other game will ever be this good. The more you play the more you discover, the more you share with your opponent the more you learn. It is philosophy, it is ideology, it is life-style... all crammed into this one huge awesome fantastic game. The absolutely best! Unmatched.

You can challenge me anytime on www.gameknot.com, my username is the same as here.

[b]- Game for pros![/b]
[b]- Stood the test of time! Playing this since 1987 and I keep on playing every day at least one move per day![/b]

RATING: 2
Probably the most overrated game of all times. Very limited mechanics leads to a very low skill level. This is the most advanced memory game ever invented. The more you remember the more games you win. Ok, I agree memorizing moves is a skill, but there is no tactics or strategic skills in this game whatsoever. For a computer it's not a memorygame, its calculation. The computer that manage to calculate the most possible moves will win.

[Fellow]: 'Wait a mo... just loading my shotgun... now.. let me put this in yer mouth'

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ive spent so much time on this game in my life I cannot give it anything lower.  Boy, it feels great to win.  But the amount of study required to reach the higher levels takes a lot of the fun out of it; studying opening lines is a total bore.  For two experienced players evenly matched, there is a definite advantage to going first.  The player with the black pieces seems to either have to play for a draw, or commit to something risky to try for a win.  Draws are much too common at the higher levels.  Games with fast time controls will always be a blast for me to play, but I think I am beginning to lose interest in the drawn out multi-hour games of tournament play.  There are also some chess variants becoming popular.  I think the jury is still out on Chess 960 (Fischer Random).  Bughouse is a multiplayer variant that is a ton of fun.

RATING: 6
A good game, but not worth of the insane amount of attention it gets.  Seems like what usually ends up happening is a whole lot of posturing until someone bites and sets off a chain reaction which removes a bunch of pieces of both colors.  Then, more posturing, more piece exchanging, and then you end up in an end-game where one player is trying to checkmate, and the other player is just trying to avoid checkmate.

(5+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
King of games. For a reason. Yes, it has grown problematic that computers are beating everyone now, so don't play them. Introduce a chess clock to bring life back into your play. True, more fun will be had if you can find equal level opponents. This game to me is the ultimate gateway game. Almost everyone has played it once, and if you are gentle, you can talk people into it, and steer the conversation toward other games. It is a fantastic bridge-builder between ages of people (kids can play well against adults), a wonderful mental exercise, and a national obsession for many parts of Europe. It handicaps easily with a clock, or by subtracting pawns, or by playing black. If you tire of the memorization of openings, play Fischerandom!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
This game is a classic. You never know when your knowledge of chess will pay off. Get in a heated discussion? Settle it with a chess match.

This is a perfect example of a great game, which is why a lot of people don't play it. It has absolutely no luck mechanics, requires deep look-ahead, and doesn't have comeback mechanics.

On the down side, it's absolutely brutal for beginners. They'll have no chance against an experience player, and if you're the expert, you'll be able to crush them so hard they'll never play you again. If that's what you're looking for, this is definitely the game for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Superb game per se. But. The playing time is faaar too long if played correctly. And that leads to me playing faaar too aggresively, which usually means either win a short game or loose the queen early :)
Very good game though. A pity it does not really encourage attack but instead defence. Would probably not play it today when there's so much else to choose among these days. Hence the rating.

RATING: 5.5
Chess is always a wonderful game - one I haven't seem to mastered.  I always enjoy playing, but quite often get my butt kicked.  (For the record, I tend to start with a good strategy, but often get overly focused on my attacks and miss seeing the attacks being made upon me....)  With that said, I still find it a wonderful game to pull out fairly often.  I consider this a complex abstract stategy game, meaning there are lots of types of moves the pieces can do - compared to a simple abstract strategy game where only a few types of moves are allowed.  Decreased rating - I have found too many games that have the same strategic value that I find more fun.

RATING: 6
I suppose I rate this only a 6 *not* because I'm no good at it -- I'm no good at lots of games -- but because (a) it's so familiar, even iconic, to so many people that it's hard to generate enthusiasm for it as a game, rather than as a kind of cultural touchstone, and (b) for what it is, a largely abstracted capture-based wargame, other games play out that theme better.  Even Stratego adds the 'fog of war' to the matrix, improving on Chess.

RATING: 7
My rating is by BGG standards.  Chess (along with Go) is perhaps the greatest game ever invented.  C'mon -- what other game in western history has ever attained this kind of iconic (and, indeed, real) significance?  A study in elegance; a remarkable balance of the abstract and the real (unlike Go).  No other game in existence rewards such deep study, or possesses such a deep history.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
-

The greatest 2-player game ever. Time-tested and time-proven. Purest form of strategy and tactics. Amazingly, dozens of people on this board have rated chess 1's 2's and 3's!! One of the given reasons is that players who have read books on chess have a huge advantage. Of course they do! Just as with any board game (of limited luck and randomness,) the more you play and the more you analyze your moves and your mistakes, the better you get at it, and will have an advantage over the other players. Chess, obviously has been around for centuries and as a result has been played billions of times and every move scrutinized, and thousends of sequences of opening moves have been analyzed in depth. Naturally, players who spend the time and effort to learn lots of opening move variations have an advantage. This is true of any game, particularly 2-player games in which no elements of luck or random events are involved (dice, event cards, etc.)

However, I do understand these people's point of view. If there is too big of gap between the skills (and/or the opening move repertoire) of the two players, the fun factor will be practically non-existent for both players (especially for the stronger player!)

Another stated reason for giving chess a low rating has been, "it is boring". This cannot be further from the truth. Chess might look boring only to the impatient and may I say, to those who have little or shallow understanding of the game. Chess has inspired millions to write books about it. Do you really think a boring game is capable of generating so much inspiration and interest?

How many books would you think will be written about Puerto Rico in the next five hundred years?

(Puerto Rico is the current #1 game on BGG, as of Feb. 2005.  And don't get me wrong-- in my opinion Puerto Rico IS the best multi-player board game at the present time.)

-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2

Try Go instead.  An infinitely superior game.

RATING: 6.5
Ah Chess.  I have a strange love-affair with this game.  Sometimes I like it and sometimes I hate it.  I learned the basics back in middle/high school.  My father, as he did with many games, taught me how to play by ruthlessly beating me multiple times until I started to understand the strategy behind the game.  I'm still not the greatest, but I occasionally surpise myself, especially in "speed chess" where you only have a total of 5 minutes per player per game (recorded on a time clock).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Oh, Chess, the deserved most respected game (or is it a sport?).
Sure it's a wargame: two opposing armies fighting against each other on a square battlefield, positioning their units in the best spots, combinating them to destroy enemy pieces, till one captures another's king. Feels like war from the very first move, 100% direct confrontation.
It's a superb game, deep and elegant, but has also some weak points:
* it plays slow (there are some quick variants but they're not true chess). After the first ones, each move is a solitaire deep mental exercise that requires complete silence.
* it's not only about talent, it needs two equally prepared players (which is hard to find). I, that once read and studied some chess, would beat my wife and friends 10 out of 10 plays easily, but high level players would beat me badly too without any tension.
So usually we play other games that besides thinking allow for talking and laughing, and where the winner is not known before the start.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rating is for more than just the game - it's for the social and support structure that surrounds it.
Classic game, with almost endless depth.
Problems are the game pushes you towards AP, and rewards people who study book openings the most. However, the more you study other people's strategies, the less of you you bring to the game. The game becomes how much of OTHER people you have absorbed.
This inevitable decline means that for me, the game ceased being fun past the casual youth level.

RATING: 6
Many plays throughout the years, since about age 9 or 10.  Not sure what it says about me, but once I get to the mid-game, I can't keep track of all of the possibilities and my game goes to hell.  Heck, it's probably gone there even before mid-game--I am just to slow to realize it.  I am very likely to give up a big piece as a result of missing a trap or a fork or simply by leaving myself open to an unseen threat.  And now that you know that about me, it should be easy to beat me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[b]RO:[/b] [i]03/07/2016[/i]

Chess. One does not bash Chess. The game of kings, the game people advise those in military command to study to help them think more strategically. A game of perfect information, of zero luck, and infinite re-themeability (Look it's a Beverly Hillbillies vs. Aliens Chess set!). And I... do not like Chess. Couldn't ever get into it. I'll play it, but I'm not especially good at it and I probably won't have fun. It's an abstract and I tend not to enjoy those very much, I also don't really like games that have [i]no[/i] luck (conversely I [i]hate[/i] games that have a very high degree of luck). And I'd like to know [i]why[/i] this was (mostly was, not so much now I reckon) considered such a great strategic training game. Luck, or at least chance, is an [i]enormous[/i] factor in war and most "war games" acknowledge this in spades with their mechanics.

Anyway, Chess is amazing for it's ability to stand the test of time (how likely is it that we will be playing Agricola in 500 years? Not very) but it just doesn't tickle my fancy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
no luck - pure skill, can make games very lopsided if players are of different levels

I'm playing it more and it's definitely a classic game, but it can be just so deterministic sometimes. I mean if you do not see a move coming, then BAM you are gone. Of course at that point, you might want to forfeit, but yes it can be unforgiving and brutal.

This rating is apparently famous. I mean it's a good game. It's just very... unforgiving. Losing a good piece can domino into a loss. The only hope is that the other guy will make a large mistake as well. But if you've lost a piece, you're probably more likely to make a mistake, SO YOU DIE.

I just think in the game you have to be laser precise, unlike say Race for the Galaxy where I have some leeway in going several directions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I've got a glass chess set that's missing a white pawn.  I also lose about 95% of the chess games that I play. I don't enjoy chess because I find it difficult to imagine what strategy my opponent might employ. I don't care to read up on chess strategy and I don't particularly care for how little delight I feel when I play chess.  Consequently, I tend to play chess very rarely. In fact, now that I own games that allow the people I play with to get their fill of strategy and tactics while still allowing me to feel at least small delights, I will probably not play chess ever again.

RATING: 6
Chess stresses me out.  The problem is that I *used* to be quite good, way back in grade school.  I played in tournaments around my state at the high school level.  I don't know about other people, but for me it is *NOT* like riding a bike, it doesn't just come back to me.  So now, after not playing for 15+ years except for the casual game every other year or so, I feel myself playing and know that I used to be better.  I fall prey to things I should have seen coming from miles away and make mistakes I never would have made before, and it all just frustrates me to no end.

RATING: 7
About once per decade I become re-fascinated by chess. Then I read some more books, play against computers, sons, and friends, and dust off the chess clock. After a few weeks, my fundamental ADD raises its scatter-brained head and I realize anew that I haven't the long-term patience needed to master this game. The books go back on the shelf, and I go back to less-intense gaming challenges.

RATING: 9.1
I've wasted way too much time in my life on chess....ever since my mother-in-law bought me a copy of chessmaster when I was in graduate school.  I play at itsyourturn.com (ID=rjcharte).....give me a game sometime!

I always have a game of chess set-up on my desk at work.  Good for some stop-in conversations and discussion of strategy and tactics.

If you haven't played chess with a clock, give it a try ....it adds a new dimension to the game.....once you've played with a clock you won't go back!!  5 minute blitz chess with an equal opponent is a gaming experience that is very difficult to match.

RATING: 10
The game of Chess is not merely an idle amusement. Several very valuable qualities of the mind, useful in the course of human life, are to be acquired or strengthened by it, so as to become habits, ready on all occasions. For life is a kind of chess, in which we have often points to gain, and competitors or adversaries to contend with, and in which there is a vast variety of good and ill events, that are, in some degree, the effects of prudence or the want of it.

RATING: 4
As always, '4' is based on my personal motivation to play. There certainly isn't anything "wrong" with Chess—in fact, quite the opposite—but....

Well, one, I, however much I admire many of them, am not an abstract person. I admire the thought and depth and practice that is sunk into this game on a daily basis by more people than will ever hear of some of my favorite games.

Two, I, unlike them, *have* heard of other games, and I'm much too busy trying to do more than just scratch the surface of a good number of great games, to be able to do the same with Chess. If I wasn't busy with an impossible number of hobbies, I might be able to settle down with Chess and give it the appreciation it deserves. But my mental space is far too clamorous for that to happen.

RATING: 7
What to say about chess? I hardly ever play this any more, but I used to be quite serious. Unfortunately, I am out of practice and so my willingness to play is lowered. In the back of my head every once in a while, I think that I should start to get good again, but the allure of tournaments has kind of faded for me. Maybe I'll pick it up again in 30 years or so.

RATING: 8.7
Which of the current Top 100 games will end up with the staying power of chess?  Do we really expect folks to be playing Settlers or Ticket to Ride or Carcassonne in four hundred years?  Longevity in and of inself is not a good enough criterion for a game to be great.  But when it's added to terrific strategy, logic, low levels of luck, and great accessibility then you've got one heck of a game.

RATING: 8
Chess is the kind of game that the more you play, the more you like it.  When you learn to sympathise with the plight of bishops, to make your head dance with action when studying lines of attack, it becomes that much more interesting.  That is to say, the interesting stuff is what's going in your head, not interaction with your opponent.  I personally like GO better--go lights up more parts of my brain than does Chess--but chess is still fun and has the advantage that most people in the US know how to play.
