=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've had a long relationship with Chess, as described in this category's header. It began to wane after high school, though, and I never really picked it up again. Go hit like lightning a decade and a bit later, and I haven't looked back.

It was only after about 10 years of Go that I've begun to want to play other abstracts, which is nice (and more social). I had a brief flirtation with the GIPF games, owning all of them and playing them as a group, as recommended, but they didn't stick. I've found that post finding Go, I am not so interested in abstracts where the pieces move about willy nilly. I want something where a piece stays where I put it. Capturing is ok, but my strategic mind wants to be able to rely on something, an ever changing framework of stability, to base subsequent moves off of. THe slow building, the repurposing of previously played pieces, the long term implications of long ago placed pieces, that is exciting to me now.

Playing Chess nowadays is like watching Basketball after watching the World Cup. Going from scoreless games, or 1-5 points total scored by both teams over hours, to points being slammed in every 30 seconds, as fast as they can be counted, you have 50! no, 100! why not! feels a little trashy or something (no offence to basketball players, fans! I'm obviously a sports Philistine).

So, I gravitate toward Hex, Blokus, Quoridor, etc. I break out a chess set every now and then, but mainly speed games--if you're going to play trashy, let's get into it! To be honest the speed also assists my playstyle--I was never very good at opening or mid-game, but I was an end game wizard. "I have to get like 75% of the pieces off of the board, so I can think!" I used to say to myself, trading anything I could, for any reason. I could have seen at that point that Chess wasn't my best game, I suppose...but when I went to high school, it wasn't like there were any other games that offered endless opponents, intellectual and competitive recognition or accolades, so I was stuck with it.

I still have my high school chess sets--the travel one my math teacher (/chess mentor) gave to me in grade 11, and the expensive one with weighted wooden pieces and large heavy board my mother bought for me in grade 10, though, so nostalgia pulls heavy on this one obviously. 

Despite all of the above flaws, I can't get rid of this one, or stop playing when asked. Or rate it lower. Humans are so confusing...



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Playing a game with one-minute turns is fun. 

I might not be quite as bad at this as I thought. I don't always have a real nuanced idea of what I'll do many turns ahead and am not sure I can given another player's unpredictable input, but I do have general ideas and find that swarming often creates check/mate/resignation situations. 

As a kid I took this game off-board, ranging the pieces across my fireplace and carpet, throwing pieces at one another as a mode of attack. If an opponent's piece was knocked over, it was taken. Now that's a wargame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best game ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really should get around to playing and studying some more chess. I think I've learnt as much as I can by stumbling through casual games. Games that take a lifetime to master are a bit annoying, but it's nice to have a meatier game that everyone around the world is familiar with.

The only reason that I don't rate this higher is that the early game can be quite cluttered (at my low skill level, anyway). And it seems that if you are trailing, it's difficult to leap into the lead with a brilliant move, because a mate later in the game (i.e. a non-smothered mate) usually requires a piece advantage.

A fine game, but with its drawish tendencies (to the point where aiming for a draw is a valid strategy) and lack of a handicap system, it doesn't hold a candle to shogi or go in terms of playability, IMO. I would like to play with a shogi style handicap or different clock times for each player, if that were acceptable to the chess community.

My master plan is to one day beat my GameBoy (original) at this on the third lowest setting. So take my criticisms here with a grain of salt.

RATING: 7
Just wish to be clear that the relatively low rating is based on my hesitation to play, although I do go through phases of being fired up about the game. Half an hour spent reading up on basic strategy ought to open up the game for most people, and disprove the usual silly objections about it being a game that rewards memorizing sequences of opening moves. Not that people have to like chess, but when BGGers call the game 'broken,' well, they sound a little bit ridiculous. 

First game my wife and I played together. Mrs Schkff comes from one of those cultures where chess is routinely played in school and everybody knows how to play.

Edit : am upping my rating, as there's no way I'd turn down a game or three, and am happy being beaten by someone who can really play, or else coaching someone in the basics. Chess is fun! 

Theme somewhat pasted on, though, it has to be admitted. And what self-respecting king would marry a pawn, just because it made its way across a battlefield? Tsk.  

Edit again 2014: Rating dropped a point again - am just not feeling the Chess love at the moment. Thjis may change as the kids get old enough to learn.

RATING: 6
You know what you're getting into with chess, and it's not too hard to find opponents who'll give you a game without any need for rules refreshers. Since my youth (where I played it quite a bit), I've enjoyed picking this up for the odd game now and then, but it fails to excite me. In order to play well you're going to need to really study the game, and I'm just not that interested in investing the time in something this dry and abstract. At the end of the day I'd rather invest the time in an historical simulation game - something from Columbia Games or GMT - than this 64 square classic. It's certainly not a bad game, but just not for me.

RATING: 7
It's chess! 

Perhaps not "perfect" as some have touted it as being, but it's also not "massively over-rated" as many nay-sayers claim it to be. In reality, this is a very strategic game of cold-calculation that deserves its regal status of prestige that it has been enjoying for centuries - a real workout for the brain.

Works beautifully with variations as well, adding to its re-playability.

Az orok szerelem. Vegigkiserte gyerekkoromat, eloszor az apai nagyapam oriasi turelemmel megtanitott, majd miutan elertem a megfelelo szintet, edesapam is hajlando volt velem leulni jatszani. RATING: 10
This is it, the game that started it all for me.  Cheap, portable, and insanely deep.  You can always find an opponent or book on this game anywhere in the world, including your phone!  Every time I play, I learn something new about the game and sometimes myself, the mark of a truly great game.  Like most people, this is my first strategy game, taught to me by my father, making this more than just a game, but a vehicle to relive a piece of my childhood.  Often, while looking at the board, I reflect on my past, those that played Chess during historic times, the great masters, and the politics of nations that surrounded this game.  Thats when Chess becomes more than just a board, pieces, a puzzle to solve, and an opponent to beat, for me it becomes something so much larger.  Over the years I have learned to love, hate, and respect this game like no other board game, Go would be a close second.  I will always play chess to the end of my days, cherishing the time of analyzing the board, my opponents, the history of the game, and all it's lessons.  Chess can be cruel, punishing, rewarding, exhilarating, and will always be my number 1.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For the record, I have entered chess tournaments and I am a teacher who runs the chess club. There are few games that match the depth of chess. The philosophy of attack, defence and patience can be taught through this game. However, after you reach a certain level, memorization is the key. To be competitive by using reasoning, there is a high level of memorization needed. For example, I have what is called an "opening book" of moves which I use. If you are better at chess than I am, but have a poor set of opening moves, you will be at a disadvantage because you haven't taken the time to memorize sequences. There are hundreds of books on just one set of these opening moves. Don't believe me? Look up "sicilian defence" or "Roy Lopez" on amazon. 

In short, chess is a good example of why a bit of randomness or secretiveness is necessary in a game. Without one of those two things, you get chess, which is unforgiving and has an incredibly high amount of work needed to be an entry level player. 

People who say this is a perfect game, have spent too long memorizing their openings to admit it.

RATING: 7
Struggling to find something to say about this one. I mean, it's Chess; it's one of the oldest games around that's still played today.

I will say one thing; it's immediately evident that anybody who has studied Chess as an almost academic form, will immediately have an overwhelming advantage over the less experienced. There is no "pick up and play" with this game; nor is there room for even the slightest of errors. I'm not going to lie; I'm awful at this game. I prefer games with multiple options to victory, and unless given a broad arsenal in which to do that, which in this game I'm rarely given - unless against an opponent of complete and equal intellect, I'm inevitably going to lose. Badly.

RATING: 4
I dislike games of perfect information. Like other such games, Chess has the problem that the main way to do better is to look ahead farther, which is not a good quality to have in my opinion. Chess has the additional problem that small mistakes can lead to huge, permanent disadvantages which are further compounded throughout the game. 

Nevertheless, deep games are always cool to observe and discuss.

RATING: 9

Pros - Rewards the time and effort you invest (zero chance), demands planning, said to improve memory and mental aptitude, different every time.

Cons - Strength disparities MUST be compensated for; otherwise the player who is much better will always win and (perhaps) discourage the poorer player.

RATING: 8
[Thousands of plays spanning 40 years] (I started playing pretty decently in kindergarten.) Opinions of chess seem polarized, but for me it is a complex and rewarding game that has survived an incredible test of time because it is a good game. I have never read any geeky chess books, or memorized "opening gambits" - nor do I want to - but I can hold my own against some ok players. I still enjoy a game a few times each year, and I look forward to getting it out whenever my brother is in town. And yes, without a doubt, I would get smoked by any really good player.

I would rate Chess a 10, but it requires closely matched skill levels between opponents to shine at its brightest for both players.

Most recent plays Dec '16.

The first (and only) game I ever got really good at. I am pretty much always up for a game of this against any competition (although, like all games, I only play f2f). Probably the only game where I am fine getting crushed, although I rarely lose against other casual players.

Admittedly, I don't actually enjoy this enough to join a chess club, so maybe my rating is a little out of line... On the other hand, that is also true for any other game I've ever played, so I guess I'll leave it there for now. 

I tried to teach this to Michelle back when we were in high school/college, but that never worked out. As a result I rarely get to play this anymore. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I will never get to learn it as I could but I always have a special place for it inside.

RATING: 10
With the possible exception of go, there is no other game that has been the subject of so much study, or has so much depth. I would give this game an "11" if I could rate it any higher.

RATING: 6
Chess still has great value despite its simplicity exactly becasue of its age. It has a huge following, support, hordes of variants, and interesting family members in Shogi and XiangQi. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Chess has always seemed to me to be a game that stuffy intellectuals play.  Invariably, whenever I tell someone that I play a lot of board games, the question arises as to whether I play chess.  For me, chess is a game that has been analyzed to death, where one player with superior knowledge of movements will beat other players -- e.g. all strategy and knowledge, no tactics.  I prefer games where players are on a bit more of equal footing, and have to use their own wits and tactical abilities to examine and win the game.  What fun is it to sit down to a game of Puerto Rico with a player that has played 1,000 times and already knows the ideal move in every situation?  The same can be said for Chess.

I also defend my position on not playing chess by the sheer volume of analysis that is available for the game as opposed to other games.  I have been to two university libraries (University of Kansas and Kansas State) where the amount of chess analysis books can be measured in _feet_ (I think 30-40 feet in each library), whereas the books dedicated to all other games (including card games, gambling, other) is 1/6-1/4 as much.    Basically, I feel that I'm feet of reading behind the learning curve, and I'm not interested in catching up.

RATING: 6
Tough time rating this.  I'm not a huge fan of chess, simply because of the amount of study that goes into becoming a great player, but I greatly admire the simplicity of its design.  However, I'm not going to do any puzzle-solving on the web, or read any books on chess history or strategy.  The fact that I don't have the patience to keep beating my head against this particular wall by actually playing (and losing) the game repeatedly tells me that the game itself doesn't hold much appeal to me.  So my 6 rating is the BGG "willing to play sporadically if in the right mood" variety, and is not a comment on the quality of the game.

RATING: 6.7
I once read something along the lines of to improve in chess, games should be played against people whom you have about a 1/3 chance of winning. 

For me, playing against someone clearer worse than you gives little satisfaction and playing against someone who completely outclasses you gives little, if any, enjoyment. This game is best played against people with similar-ish skill who will give you a good challenge without being too easy or too hard.

RATING: 6
This game is the one I've probably played the longest in my life.  My grandfather taught me how to play on an airplane when I was 5 and I've played occasionally ever since.

Despite that, though, I'm not very good.  I just don't have the mindset to think more than 1-2 moves ahead.  I don't have this issue with many of the other strategic games I play but for some reason I do when I play Chess.  I find myself on the back foot pretty often and typically win via a lucky or tactical move in that moment or a mistake on my opponent's part.

Chess is undoubtedly deep and interesting but I'm still only good for the occasional game.  Both because I usually lose and this game more than any other makes me feel like a lesser person when I lose and because it doesn't feel as much fun as it does an examination of my intellect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic favorite, from childhood.  This game is an enigma.  With static starting positions for the last thousand years, there are many books on which moves and sequences of moves are best.  Many lengthy game sequences can be memorized from the game's beginning.  Still, the best players in the world invent new ways to win.
This is great as a casual game, rather than memorizing lengthy game sequences, you can have a fun meta-game using a few key principles from a beginner's book on chess.

RATING: 10
The King of all board games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
What can I say about a game that has been around for over 500 years, yet remains one of the most popular games in the world?  On the surface it is lovely in its simple beauty, yet below the surface it has a seemingly endless depth.  The fact that it is a game of no luck and all strategy is both its blessing and its curse, as far as I'm concerned.  I love the mental exercise of developing plans of attack and countering opponents' strategies, but I also feel like my intellect has suffered if I lose the game.  My main problems with this game are that I never seem to know what the good opening moves should be, if I get down a piece it becomes very difficult to come back, and I tend to bore my opponents by taking WAY too long to do each of my moves.  Yes, this (along with "Scrabble") is my Analysis Paralysis game, which is why I generally stick to playing online.  But that little issue is quickly solved by playing a game of five-second chess (your opponent counts out five seconds, and if you have not made your move by then, it becomes their turn again - very chaotic and confusing, but a good exercise in thinking fast after playing a regular game of careful analysis).  Of course, this is also a game where you need to have an opponent who is roughly the same skill level as yourself in order to make it a fun game for both.  Now if only I could find a Hundred Years War chess set for a reasonable price...  Game design: 5/5  Personal enjoyment: 3.5/5  Total: 8.5/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The ultimate game.  Once learnt, rarely mastered.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The absolute classic game in Western civilization.
You can enjoy it even if your level of play is not very good; the only drawback is that the gap in skill between the players is not too high, if not it kills the interest for both players. It can be played in  various formats : rapid chess (blitz), casual play and problems solving. One particular and unusual use of the chessboard is the retro-analysis problems : you only need to know the rules in order to try to solve puzzles. A real blast if you like logical puzzles! I strongly recommend the book "The Chess Mysteries of Sherlock Holmes" by Raymond Smullyan)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Chess is a game that is easy to learn but takes a lifetime to master for most, and some never reach that level at all. It is an extremely deep game that allows players to work out moves well in advance and adopt strategies for dealing with pesky opponents. The game never plays twice the same way, which is good. I don't think of it so much as "fun" as I do giving my brain a 5k run, and yet it is enjoyable. In moderation.

RATING: 10
I have played this game more times than all others put together, from ten minute games to five hour ones. For many years it was my life and I still have a library of chess books.

Even though I don't play now, I have given it a 10 because it is the perfect blend of abstract game and feel. The pieces are thematic and the openings and defences are so full of meaning to an experienced player. Despite the fact that the pieces all start on the same 32 squares and there are only 64 playing squares in total, there are still fresh themes and lines being explored 500 years after its invention.

RATING: 5.5

You discover no "new ground", but rather try to capture the opponent, which I find boring. Moreover, this game is taxing only on the tactical level, while there are no different strategies to employ. A timeless classic for sure, but I like other games better.

RATING: 7
[u]Key Words:[/u] Abstract Strategy - Classic - Luckless - 2-Player

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] Abstract tactical masterpiece.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Good game, even if I never play it.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

THE tactical masterpiece of the west.

Like Go, this game rewards careful study and rigorous training. It's entirely possible to devote your life to learning and playing it.

Even if I don't play it and never have regularly, I refuse to give it any less than 7 for its obvious depth and replayability.

RATING: 8.7
I rediscovered chess during the summer of 2014. This really is an amazing abstract. The more you play it, the more it open up. I never really cared much for poring over the board face to face so I am currently enjoying 10 min/side blitz. It's a length of game that is fast enough to allow you to make mistakes quickly and learn from them without suffering through hours of agonizing defeat.

Beer and blitz is what it's all about.

I have a user on chess.com: FBeyer 
Hit me up for a correspondance game.

Online Rating as of Oct 2014 - 1190
Online Rating as of Feb 2015 - 1426

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's fun, but after a while I realized that winning against skilled opponents came down to who had memorized more. Against more causal opponents, or my perfect equal in terms of chess knowledge it is a fascinating abstract game of tactics, deceit and mistakes. At all skill levels, it is a game won and lost on mistakes rather than on correct moves.

Chess was not reborn as a joyful game for me until I discovered the Alice variant--it involves two borads and players switch boards everytime they complete a move (this includes a capture, and the corresponding square on the opposite board must be empty for a move or capture to be legally undertaken). It was in the middle of a triple forking maneuver that, considering the movement possibilities of my opponent's surrounded king and queen and the positions of my pieces on both boards also amounted to a number of pins not geometrically possible in normal chess that I fell absolutely in love. I see your classic King's Indian Defense and raise you forced teleportation and one horrible corner to be stuck in. :D

Also, playing chess on a Kline surface is a sheer delight.

It's an average game for me without variations. With variations, the basic setup can truly become something marvelous.

RATING: 7
A true classic, but I never wanted to devote my life to mastering it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It does get the feeling of sameness after a while. Not the positions on the board, they are like snowflakes, but the thinking involved is inevitably the same. You go through the same sort of protocol for each move: am I ahead in material? should I exchange pieces? should I exchange pawns? avoid exchanges? play positionally? Petrosian said it best: "it's a wooden game, the moves are wooden, the strategies are wooden. Even the pieces are wooden." Still it's addictive....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I am bad at chess and I don't like abstracts so much. Despite that, I can appreciate that chess is a category unto itself. Chess is one of the few games that legitimately creates an emergent tapestry of strategy from a clean, elegant ruleset. The chess field is so wide that it incorporates play-styles and personalities in a way that most games only pretend to. 

Those personalities fill entire books, and they weather lifetimes of scrutiny.

RATING: 4
I've never really liked chess. Very unforgiving for new players, which I think turns a lot of people off. Some unintuitive maneuvers (e.g., castling). If you're playing someone of equal skill, you'd better enjoy their company because you're going to be there for a long time. Not fun to lose, not fun to win. Seems like most people know most of the rules, but no one has their rule sheets anymore and everybody gets offended if you want to look up a rule online.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
That's right, I'm reviewing chess.  How can one review a game that's older than any of our lifetimes, the answer is: Its not easy.  Chess is timeless, It's infinitely complex, has been redesigned component wise more times than god and the depth is astounding. Truly it is the starting point of strategy games, while at the same time the grandfather to so much more.  The pressure on the win and loss stems from a cerebral exercise making it seem like an accomplishment to win (a key factor to the enjoyment stemming from pure strategy).  However I've always found my big determent to chess is the play time.  Chess really isn't that exciting by modern standards (not that its supposed to be).  The endless struggle of attack and defense will carry through history however and as such that says something as a testiment to the game.  All these things considered there's so many other games I would rather play than a game of chess.  Games have since evolved and arched in so many different flavors and since my 6 yearold self I have since lost a taste for it.  That being said, chess gets a 7.

RATING: 4
Nice idea poorly implemented.
The size of the pieces does not reflect traditional size relationships. Frodo, the bishop, is the smallest of the back row pieces. The Ringwraith queen is taller than Saruman the king. 
Most of the piece assignments don't make much sense.  Frodo mis more logically a knight than a bishop, which should be represented by Aragorn--not only for movement purposes, but because his character is much better suited to that role. The cave trolls are bishops!? These definitely belong at the end of the row, as rooks.
I hate, also that these guys are too big for the squares. Make a board big enough for your pieces, please! There is plenty of room in the box.

Although I enjoy many traditional boardgames, they don't produce this same level of excitement for me. [Full disclosure: I'm terrible at chess!]

RATING: 6
Signor Gaspare replied: "And what do you say about the game of chess?"

"That is certainly a refined and ingenious recreation," said Federico, "but it seems to me to possess one defect; namely, that it is possible for it to demand too much knowledge, so that anyone who wishes to become an outstanding player must, I think, give to it as much time and study as he would to learning some noble science or performing well something or other of importance; and yet for all his pains when all is said and done all he knows is a game. Therefore as far as chess is concerned we reach what is a very rare conclusion: that mediocrity is more to be praised than excellence."

-- Etiquette for Renaissance Gentlemen

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's hard for me to even consider analysing, critiquing and rating such a celebrated game. Considered by many to be a 'perfect game', Chess is a giant of abstract strategy gaming; it is devoid of all luck, it is almost completely balanced (besides a slight advantage to first player) and yields a complex array of different possible moves, strategies and tactics. Entire books are dedicated to different combos of moves. And all this from a game that has been around for centuries. 

I played Chess constantly as a child, went to Chess club regularly, and grew up in a family of avid Chess players. I admire the game for what it is, and enjoy playing against opponents of a similar skill level to mine.

So do I dare critique it? Well, there are some issues for me personally. Chess is not kind to new gamers. It does not invite you in like newer games are good at doing, and it can be quite long. AP abounds. The end game can become a game of drawn out 'cat and mouse', and I feel there are games that better streamline the experience.

But for all that, it is a great game. And I have probably just personally exhausted it somewhat. Considering I've been playing it as long as I have, and can still enjoy it, says a lot. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
An eternal game, to be sure. I'm just not a huge fan. I tend to enjoy games that take a short time to learn, but a lifetime to master. But I tend to not like games where a lot of people actually do spend their lifetime trying to master it. 

I don't mind a casual game here or there, but I'm likely to lose pretty badly to anyone who plays even occasionally. I don't mind losing games, as I'm often an experiential gamer, but I find chess less rewarding because it doesn't tell a story. The game state doesn't evolve in a meaningful way to me. Whereas Go does. 

If I were going to play a chess-like game, I'd much rather play Tafl. I just find it more interesting.

LIBRARY
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The most complicated game everyone knows.  Memorize what each unit does, don't forget pawns only move forward 2 spaces if they haven't moved yet.  Oh, also there's this thing called castling.  Yeah units block, except that one unit that ignores that.  No you don't capture the king, you have to do that and make sure he can't move.  Oh, you might end up in a tie like tick-tac-toe.
This game's importance is incalculable, but there's better games out there that are more fun, easier to learn, and give just as much strategy.
Also suffers 1 player will probably beat the other every time they play.  I don't like it when 1 player just always wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I taught myself chess at around 8 or 9 years of age by reading the instructions on a family set. I played as often as I could find willing opponents, but there weren't many of those in my case. In my early twenties I became obsessed with the game and studied, researched and played daily. After two years of this obsession I quit. The reasons I quit playing would complete a dissertation. I will say that I still consider this one of the best games ever created and cannot imagine a world where chess is not taken very seriously by a lot of ridiculously talented people (who also are typically psychotic, rude, paranoid, unhealthy and generally terrible people to spend your time with).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After playing many modern board games I always come back to this classic. The reasons are as follows:
1. It plays relatively quickly
2. No dice
3. Elegant design 
4. Everyone knows how to play
5. Great spectator game (everyone has an opinion)
6. Has a great narrative arc for an abstract
7. You can find many opponents on-line at any time of the day
8. Is respected by most people (not childish in perception)
9. You can play based on your style (defensive, aggressive, or tactical)
10. Has a ton of "replayability"
11. Crosses the language barrier
12. Quick to learn, but a lifetime to master

RATING: 8
I have known how to play this game since I was 9 yo. The gameplay didn't compel me to play it obsessively then as I do now. I remember losing constantly to my dad everytime we play, and because he is very competitive he never gave a a handicap or allowed to win even once. He instead gave me a an opening book for beginners to read. I didn't read the book and have not touch a chess piece ever since.

Until I got a laptop computer with a good internet connection. You see the average person needed a to train himself regularly in order to be "mediocre" in this this game. The internet helped me do that easily. Watching IM's play chess on youtube while they verbalize their thoughts have helped me to understand how to play this game to right way. This is the game that I'd play until my old age..

RATING: N/A
(+~500 Plays before I started counting)

Best Tactical Exercise Ever. If you want to try your mind against someone else, that's it.

It can take hundreds of matches to catch up with a better player, and the amount of concentration and brainburning required for a good match easilly qualifies chess as a mind exercise rather than a game.

I honestly think it shouldn't be here in the geek with the boardgames, as the purpose of chess is complelly different, and loving chess has absolutely nothing to do with loving boargames. Therefore I've completely removed my rating for it (initially it was 10) .

The following has nothing to do with my rating but it is awesome.  From http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/18878/item/365361?commentid=680332

"I have heard it explained that, within chess, the movement of the pieces represents how their loyalty is split between the Church and the Crown. Orthogonal movement represents political (Crown) affiliation, and diagonal movement represents religious (Church) affiliation.

So, Bishops are exclusively loyal to the Church, while Rooks are exclusively loyal to the Crown. The King and Queen serve both, but not at the same time. Pawns move at the command of the Crown, but fight for their Church. Knights, with their code of chivalry, are sworn to serve both equally. So the Knights' L-Shaped movement is actually a political action combined with a religious action."

RATING: 8
PROS: The king of all abstract strategy games. Fully tactical, no luck, brain-burner gameplay. A classic in every way;

CONS: Requires an opponent of the same skill level than you to be enjoyable; The basic rules are not so complex but also not enough for someone to fully understand the game: There are a LOT of small tactical details that need to be studied, learned and trained, so the game isn't very friendly to a new player; I consider it more a sport than a board game, because the only way to become really good at it is by taking it seriously and dedicating time to study and practice.

RATING: 6
Chess and its cousins interest me but I'm not good at them.

I definitely don't care for the aimless early game and the endgames where a few pieces run around unable to catch each other.

...I want to like chess etc. but it just solos terribly. Invariably I find that I've ignored (as both sides) a huge and obvious opportunity for one side, and that destroys the game. Why? Not just because the current game state should not have existed, but because in order to continue I have to arbitrarily decide which player gets to either take advantage of the opportunity or take action to eliminate it.

More generally chess just has too many moves to evaluate at one time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
For the game, I'd give 5. Fact is that chess outcome is always draw (if players are equal). The winning - losing difference comes from the fact that one side, or other did not scan through (or forgot, while dying in boredom) all information about established moves/counter moves.

Every once and a while, one manages to beat decent chess player by doing something unexpected and borderline ridiculous. In these occasions game can momentarily be fun before player who deviated from The True Way(tm) is quickly beaten to death by community that does not allow anyone to deviate from the Established Truth and Scripture(tm). Hence, due to players being what they are, rating is 2.

In any case, Shogi is much, much better game of this genre.

RATING: N/A
El ajedrez es un juego de estrategia abstracta para dos jugadores que representa la guerra medieval en un tablero de 8x8 con luz y cuadrados oscuros alternantes. piezas opuestas, tradicionalmente designados Blanco y Negro, están alineados inicialmente a cada lado. Cada tipo de pieza tiene una forma única de movimiento y la captura se produce cuando una pieza, a través de su movimiento, ocupa la plaza de una pieza oponente. Los jugadores se turnan para mover una de sus piezas en un intento de capturar, ataque, defender o desarrollar sus posiciones. juegos de ajedrez pueden terminar en jaque mate, renuncia, o uno de varios tipos de sorteos. El ajedrez es uno de los juegos más populares en el mundo, jugado por millones de personas en todo el mundo en casa, en los clubes, en línea, por correspondencia, y en los torneos. Entre dos jugadores muy cualificados, el ajedrez puede ser una cosa digna de ver, y un juego puede proporcionar un gran entretenimiento incluso para los principiantes. También hay una gran cantidad de literatura de libros y publicaciones periódicas sobre el ajedrez, por lo general con juegos y comentarios de los maestros de ajedrez.
La forma actual del juego surgió en el sur de Europa durante la segunda mitad del siglo 15 después de evolucionar a partir de un juego similar, mucho más antigua de origen indio. La tradición de ajedrez competitivo organizado comenzó en el siglo 16. El primer oficial Campeón Mundial de Ajedrez, Wilhelm Steinitz, reclamó su título en 1886. El actual campeón del mundo es Magnus Carlsen, Noruega. El ajedrez es un deporte reconocido del Comité Olímpico Internacional.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Wooden, folding chess set with wooden pieces.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have a large collection of Staunton Chess Sets, some antique, some contemporary (Four Bakelite sets, one ivory set, one leaded glass set handmade in 1990 by myself - pictured). I have more than 60 tournament sized Staunton design sets including chessmen of various materials (wood, stone, marble, metal, bakelite, plastic, bone, ivory, etc.), several full-sized chess boards, 4 chess clocks, a fairly large library of chess books and software, including several strong iPhone players. Fritz is running on my PC, iPhone, PS3 and Nintendo DS. Internet Chess Club (ICC) is fantastic!

I have a devotional love for this game.  With the single exception of Go (and, perhaps, Xiangqi)... no other game on the planet ever has evolved such a deep and rich set of tactics and strategy requiring studying various parts of the game's progress (opening, middle, and endgame) to achieve such a widely variable ability rating compared with other players... No other game has established such a worldwide following of players... No other game has such an interesting history in terms of players and tournaments extending back decades (and centuries)... No other game has such a large number of collectors of fine, antique, sometimes rare or unique playing pieces. More books have been written about chess than any other single subject in the history of mankind, and are still being published at a faster rate. There are several libraries on the planet housing nothing but chess books!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Only truely balanced strategical as well as tactical turn-based game around of unparalleled depth; suited for both positional styled stranglers and hyper agressive regicides; playtimes adaptable to taste and ranging from 1 minute bullet to 10-day per turn correspondence modes; easy to learn but still with a steep (that is to say: never ending) learning curve, which is of no consequence to enjoyment, since a multitude of equaly ept or (inept) opponents is available everywhere on the globe for players of all levels, online as well as IRL.

Chess being an abstract game, representing the feudal society at war, its central theme of the King Hunt doesn't make it feel rather the opposite of a "detached" abstract game. Get the men (& Queen!) ready! You too Bishop! Everybody has to contribute, war is coming!

RATING: 4
*sigh* This game is only alive because of its age and the less intelligent minds of the past several hundred years.

I will admit I liked chess, but then as I played more and more I found there were very specific strategies to employ with no diversion from pattern.  It went from a game of observing and planning, to a game of memorization.  The strategic depth in the modern day I honestly have to say is on par with Pac-Man...

In closing of this short review, there's a reason people are making variant rules to the game, and why the original is timed so harshly.

Wouldn't you prefer a game of global thermonuclear war?

RATING: 10
This is the one that started it all for me.  I've never really made a priority of learning to be a great player, but I love casual games.  I'm not convinced that there is a greater depth of strategy in chess than in other games, but what depth there is is well understood by a cadre of experts who have written extensively on the subject.  So, chess is a rare beast in gaming that rewards formal study as well as casual exploration.  It's a perfect meta-gaming example of "multiple paths to victory"

RATING: 9
Yeah, yeah, people rag that it's all about memorization, but really that only gets you through the opening.  You can compensate for memorization, and if you can get the other player out of book, you have a superb game. It's area control and influence in one of its purest forms.  I haven't played this for a long time, but every once in a while I'll go on a chess kick and suddenly everything will become a chessboard:  the dinner table, the freeway, the sidewalk...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I know how to play Chess, but not well.  One of those games i'd have to devote way too much time to playing in order to play as well as i'd like.  Even so, I still enjoy the game.

RATING: 6
Κάθε παίκτης ξεκινά την παρτίδα με 16 πεσσούς κάθε ένας των οποίων ανήκει σε κάποιο είδος που έχει τον δικό του ιδιαίτερο τρόπο κίνησης και αιχμαλώτισης αντιπάλων κομματιών. Συγκεκριμένα έχει οκτώ πιόνια, δύο πύργους, δύο ίππους, δύο αξιωματικούς, μία βασίλισσα και έναν βασιλιά. Ο ένας παίκτης κατέχει τα λευκά και ο άλλος τα μαύρα, όπως ονομάζονται οι αντιστοίχου χρώματος πεσσοί.

Ο σκοπός κάθε παίχτη είναι η επίτευξη ματ στον αντίπαλο βασιλιά. Αυτό συμβαίνει όταν ο βασιλιάς απειλείται (αυτό ονομάζεται σαχ) και δεν υπάρχει νόμιμη κίνηση διάσωσης. Ας σημειωθεί ότι το ματ καθιστά την αιχμαλώτιση του βασιλιά περιττή καθώς αποτελεί το τέλος του παιχνιδιού.

RATING: 6
A mentally stimulating abstract game, but over centuries of analysis it has become overly formulaic and memorization-based.  Static opening play with non-intuitive mechanics that punish every error. Poor aesthetics.

Or, alternatively, an immensely deep and storied game that I am simply to impatient to study enough to reach a level of enjoyable competency.

I play and enjoy; but mostly because it helps me defend my reputation for intelligence.  Fess up, BGG'ers...

RATING: 7
I think I'd actually like chess more if it was less popular. Not because of any kind of elitism or anything, but because it's been studied to death by even a lot of average people. If I play with someone else who doesn't have a ton of experience and/or has not read about strategy, I enjoy it well enough (though not as much as many other 2-player games), but someone who has read even cursory articles about tactics will just systematically break me down, and at that point it feels more like an exam than a game. I mention the popularity because I get the feeling I'd feel the same way about Puerto Rico if most people I play with were tournament players.

RATING: 7
Any game that has had this much written about it and has such a high profile cannot be a bad game. And of course chess is not, it is one of the best games ever created.

I think the reason why it is not rated more highly here on BGG (and by me) is that it is a very difficult game to play: it requires a very specific type of intelligence, it has absolutely zero luck and the theme is - well, it is not Race for the Galaxy or Combat Commander is it! I think all of these things makes the people here on BGG uncomfortable, hence its low rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Snakes & Lattes Recommended
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What to say about Chess? It's very abstract, very deep, very good. Sometimes more work than fun, but has a sharp clarity that many abstract games lack, most being more incremental affairs (cf. Go or Backgammon). The ubiquity of computers with Chess now is a bittersweet development, one presciently anticipated by Fischer (among others).  I think as a pure "game," Chess960 will gain more and more traction.

Also, I must admit that by far the most interesting part of Chess is the midgame.  Openings can be rote, and endgames can be tedious in the extreme. But it is a great, subtle and yet dynamic game: so much can turn on one move, and yet it may not be apparent until 10 moves later.

Also, I had never played much with a clock, but having done so recently, I highly recommend it.  Great fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Wooden version
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hey, its chess what needs to be said?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
When I was about four years old, I found a cool old travel chess set in my great granddad's basement.  He showed me how each piece moved and told me that I could keep the set if I could memorize each movement by the end of the weekend.  It seemed like a monumental task at the time, but I earned that first chess set and have been playing ever since.

The key to enjoying chess is just to find somebody that is about at your skill level.  You don't have to devote your life to it.  I play email chess with one of my best friends that now lives across the country.  Great way to keep in touch and keep the mind sharp!

RATING: 6
Like most, I have various chess sets, with a couple being favorites of mine.  

I acknowledge that it's a great, historical game, yet I rate it a 6 purely because of my personal preferences.  I enjoy a game from time to time, but there's many other games I enjoy better.

I don't do well with planning out several moves in advace.  Frankly, I'm just not that good.  I enjoy different chess variants more than the standard chess game.

It's a wonderful game ... I just don't want to play it frequently.

RATING: 6
Own two copies: one is beat-up generic set with plastic pieces, the other is themed after the recent Transformers films with large, heavy-duty plastic pieces.

I haven't actually played this in several years, but it can be very enjoyable when played with someone of a similar skill level. It quickly becomes less and less fun as the skill gap widens, and if the outcome is known before you even begin the game, no thanks.

Given a choice I'd much rather play a "variant" like [thing=6848][/thing].  It uses many similar mechanisms, but adds far more variability and even a small dose of randomness that makes it infinitely more fun to play even when the player skill levels are mismatched.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.8
Has the same problems all symmetric abstracts have, going first is an advantage. It is one of the classics that everyone should play and teaches a lot, but has no mitigation of first player advantage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
You really have to play against someone of your skill level, though, as the ability to step through subsequent moves in your mind is a definite acquired talent.  And, someone who can only see 1 or 2 moves ahead will never, at all, EVER win a game against someone who can easily calculate a dozen moves ahead.  Given the right pair, though, the game is brilliant.  Easy mechanics, lots of sets to choose from - so component quality can be very high, lots of 'external' material to reference, definite game flow (clear beginning, middle, and end of match), etc.  Personal favorite aspect is chess 'puzzles', which are GREAT for solitaire enjoyment of the game (perhaps the *only* game I enjoy 'solitaire' for this reason).  In fact, a Chess puzzle app is the only 'game' on my iPhone at the moment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hard to go wrong with an ancient classic. Fun and enjoyable so long as you're playing at the casual level (~1 hour games tops) with relatively comparable opponents. I don't consider it a "gaming" game and would never play it with opponents who were willing to play a Euro or Ameritrash game instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
It's the Monopoly of 2-player abstracts!  Seriously: even as a variant of chess it sucks!

Okay I admit I'm deliberately trying to deflate its bgg rating.  And to be honest, I carry a pocket magnetic set everywhere and I've played it more often, with a greater variety of people, and in more cheap cafes, campus pubs, job sites, buses and beautiful parks than any other game. In a sense, it really is *the* game of my life. Also, it's unqualified fun with Karten Schach (see that rating). 

But tradition and custom shouldn't inflate bgg rating. There are several original abstracts on this site and even classical variants that are far superior to this in design.

RATING: 4
If I were to play this with someone who also has never studied the game, I would find it just a little less fun than [thing=2065]Shogi[/thing] or [thing=2393]Xiang Qi[/thing].  Those games have few or no pieces that can travel the length of the board in one move.  Having to check every bloody piece in [International] Chess wearies me a bit, and reduces my enjoyment of it.
Unfortunately, pretty much anybody I know who would want to play this with me has either studied it, or played it enough to completely guarantee their victory.  I don't mind losing, but I don't have much fun at abstract strategy games when the outcome is a foregone conclusion - yes, even if it were because I won every time.

Things I prefer about [thing=2065]Shogi[/thing] over Chess:
You only have to get your unit to the furthest third (rather than eighth) of the board to promote it.
You can promote every unit except the jeweled general (king), though whether you want to promote a unit will depend on the situation.
Rather than moving a unit, you can place a unit you captured on the board, in your employ.

Things I prefer about [thing=2393]Xiang Qi[/thing] over Chess:
Some of your units may not cross the river into enemy territory.
Three of your units, including the emperor, may not leave the 3×3 palace in the back middle of your territory.
The cannon can only capture by jumping over precisely one piece, which provides tricky ways to block its tricky attack.
Before any moves are made, pieces are already in threat of capture, making every move feel significant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of the first games I was taught. Probably typical for a child of Eastern European immigrants. I remember being taught at 4 and losing quickly to my father. I only found out much later that he played at a master level and when I finally was able to beat him in my teens I was super happy. 

Of course, chess is also a game that brings out the worst in people. I remember one game I played with a poser in university who would comment on your play the whole game and then give you his "ranking". Such a tool, especially since he didn't play all that well and was more into mocking others to throw them off their game than to actually focus on gameplay. 

Keeping with tradition, when my kids were 4 I taught them chess. Sadly, they didn't enjoy it as much as I did and rarely played it as they got older. Interestingly enough my son now wants to play my father. Hopefully they'll both get time to do that before it's too late.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It never dies.

RATING: 9
Quintessential in: Catch a prey, nothing else counts. Blocking at the rules level (stalemate) is a draw. More deeply rooted in its culture than the other abstracts. Somewhat tainted, but still beautiful. Just see the delicate balance of bishops and knights.

As for computers, hey, I have a grandmaster at home commenting on my games. Smoke that in your pipe.
